And if you have the right expectations and expectation management, we feel like it's going to be a pretty gratifying experience.RG: And so this is what — And we think that a lot of parents, when you get in there — in our case anyway — you pack your bags for a trip to Europe, and you're really excited to go. Get out of the airplane, it turns out you're trekking in Nepal. And trekking in Nepal is an extraordinary experience, particularly if you pack your bags properly and you know what you're getting in for and you're psyched. So the point of all this for us today is not just hopefully honesty for the sake of honesty, but a hope that by being more honest and candid about these experiences, that we can all collectively bend that happiness baseline up a little bit.RG + AV: Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
Alisa Volkman: So this is where our story begins --

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:19.958
the dramatic moments of the birth

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:21.958
of our first son, Declan.

00:00:21.958 --> 00:00:23.958
Obviously a really profound moment,

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.958
and it changed our lives in many ways.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
It also changed our lives in many unexpected ways,

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
and those unexpected ways we later reflected on,

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
that eventually spawned a business idea between the two of us,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
and a year later, we launched Babble,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
a website for parents.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
Rufus Griscom: Now I think of our story

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.958
as starting a few years earlier. AV: That's true.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
RG: You may remember, we fell head over heels in love.

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
AV: We did.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
RG: We were at the time running a very different kind of website.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
It was a website called Nerve.com,

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:53.958
the tagline of which was "literate smut."

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:56.958
It was in theory, and hopefully in practice,

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
a smart online magazine

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:01.958
about sex and culture.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
AV: That spawned a dating site.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
But you can understand the jokes that we get. Sex begets babies.

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:09.958
You follow instructions on Nerve and you should end up on Babble,

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
which we did.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:14.958
And we might launch a geriatric site as our third. We'll see.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
RG: But for us, the continuity between Nerve and Babble

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
was not just the life stage thing,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
which is, of course, relevant,

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
but it was really more about

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
our desire to speak very honestly

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
about subjects that people have difficulty speaking honestly about.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
It seems to us that

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
when people start dissembling, people start lying about things,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:36.958
that's when it gets really interesting.

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:38.958
That's a subject that we want to dive into.

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
And we've been surprised to find, as young parents,

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.958
that there are almost more taboos around parenting

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
than there are around sex.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
AV: It's true. So like we said,

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
the early years were really wonderful,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:51.958
but they were also really difficult.

00:01:51.958 --> 00:01:53.958
And we feel like some of that difficulty

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:56.958
was because of this false advertisement around parenting.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
(Laughter)

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
We subscribed to a lot of magazines, did our homework,

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
but really everywhere you look around, we were surrounded by images like this.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
And we went into parenting

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
expecting our lives to look like this.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
The sun was always streaming in, and our children would never be crying.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
I would always be perfectly coiffed and well rested,

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
and in fact, it was not like that at all.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
RG: When we lowered the glossy parenting magazine

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
that we were looking at, with these beautiful images,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
and looked at the scene in our actual living room,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
it looked a little bit more like this.

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
These are our three sons.

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
And of course, they're not always crying and screaming,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
but with three boys, there's a decent probability

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
that at least one of them will not be comporting himself

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
exactly as he should.

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
AV: Yes, you can see where the disconnect was happening for us.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
We really felt like what we went in expecting

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
had nothing to do with what we were actually experiencing,

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
and so we decided we really wanted to give it to parents straight.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:51.958
We really wanted to let them understand

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:54.958
what the realities of parenting were in an honest way.

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
RG: So today, what we would love to do

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
is share with you four parenting taboos.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
And of course, there are many more than four things

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
you can't say about parenting,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
but we would like to share with you today

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
four that are particularly relevant for us personally.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
So the first, taboo number one:

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:14.958
you can't say you didn't fall in love with your baby

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
in the very first minute.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
I remember vividly, sitting there in the hospital.

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:22.958
We were in the process of giving birth to our first child.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
AV: We, or I?

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
RG: I'm sorry.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
Misuse of the pronoun.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
Alisa was very generously in the process

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
of giving birth to our first child -- (AV: Thank you.)

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
-- and I was there with a catcher's mitt.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
And I was there with my arms open.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
The nurse was coming at me

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
with this beautiful, beautiful child,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
and I remember, as she was approaching me,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
the voices of friends saying,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
"The moment they put the baby in your hands,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
you will feel a sense of love that will come over you

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
that is [on] an order of magnitude more powerful

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
than anything you've ever experienced in your entire life."

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
So I was bracing myself for the moment.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
The baby was coming,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
and I was ready for this Mack truck of love

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
to just knock me off my feet.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
And instead, when the baby was placed in my hands,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
it was an extraordinary moment.

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
This picture is from literally a few seconds after

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
the baby was placed in my hands and I brought him over.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
And you can see, our eyes were glistening.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
I was overwhelmed with love and affection for my wife,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
with deep, deep gratitude

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
that we had what appeared to be a healthy child.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
And it was also, of course, surreal.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
I mean, I had to check the tags and make sure.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
I was incredulous, "Are you sure this is our child?"

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
And this was all quite remarkable.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
But what I felt towards the child at that moment was deep affection,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
but nothing like what I feel for him now, five years later.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
And so we've done something here

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
that is heretical.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
We have charted

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
our love for our child over time.

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
(Laughter)

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
This, as you know, is an act of heresy.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
You're not allowed to chart love.

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
The reason you're not allowed to chart love

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
is because we think of love as a binary thing.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
You're either in love, or you're not in love.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
You love, or you don't love.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
And I think the reality is that love is a process,

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
and I think the problem with thinking of love

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
as something that's binary

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
is that it causes us

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
to be unduly concerned

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
that love is fraudulent, or inadequate, or what have you.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:21.958
And I think I'm speaking obviously here to the father's experience.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
But I think a lot of men do go through this sense

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
in the early months, maybe their first year,

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
that their emotional response is inadequate in some fashion.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
AV: Well, I'm glad Rufus is bringing this up,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
because you can notice where he dips in the first years

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
where I think I was doing most of the work.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
But we like to joke,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
in the first few months of all of our children's lives,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
this is Uncle Rufus.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
(Laughter)

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
RG: I'm a very affectionate uncle, very affectionate uncle.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
AV: Yes, and I often joke with Rufus when he comes home

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
that I'm not sure he would actually be able to find our child in a line-up

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
amongst other babies.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
So I actually threw a pop quiz here onto Rufus.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
RG: Uh oh.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
AV: I don't want to embarrass him too much. But I am going to give him three seconds.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
RG: That is not fair. This is a trick question. He's not up there, is he?

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
AV: Our eight-week-old son is somewhere in here,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
and I want to see if Rufus can actually quickly identify him.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
RG: The far left. AV: No!

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:19.958
(Laughter)

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
RG: Cruel.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
AV: Nothing more to be said.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
(Laughter)

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
I'll move on to taboo number two.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
You can't talk about how lonely having a baby can be.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
I enjoyed being pregnant. I loved it.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
I felt incredibly connected to the community around me.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:38.958
I felt like everyone was participating in my pregnancy, all around me,

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:41.958
tracking it down till the actual due-date.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:45.958
I felt like I was a vessel of the future of humanity.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
That continued into the the hospital. It was really exhilarating.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
I was shower with gifts and flowers and visitors.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
It was a really wonderful experience,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
but when I got home,

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
I suddenly felt very disconnected

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
and suddenly shut in and shut out,

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
and I was really surprised by those feelings.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
I did expect it to be difficult,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
have sleepless nights, constant feedings,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
but I did not expect the feelings

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
of isolation and loneliness that I experienced,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
and I was really surprised that no one had talked to me,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
that I was going to be feeling this way.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
And I called my sister

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
whom I'm very close to -- and had three children --

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
and I asked her, "Why didn't you tell me

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
I was going to be feeling this way,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
that I was going to have these -- feeling incredibly isolated?"

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
And she said -- I'll never forget --

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
"It's just not something you want to say to a mother

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
that's having a baby for the first time."

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
RG: And of course, we think

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
it's precisely what you really should be saying

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
to mothers who have kids for the first time.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
And that this, of course, one of the themes for us

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
is that we think

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
that candor and brutal honesty

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
is critical to us collectively

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
being great parents.

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
And it's hard not to think

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
that part of what leads to this sense of isolation

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
is our modern world.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
So Alisa's experience is not isolated.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
So your 58 percent of mothers surveyed

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
report feelings of loneliness.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
Of those, 67 percent are most lonely

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
when their kids are zero to five -- probably really zero to two.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
In the process of preparing this,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
we looked at how some other cultures around the world

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
deal with this period of time,

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958
because here in the Western world,

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
less than 50 percent of us live near our family members,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
which I think is part of why this is such a tough period.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
So to take one example among many:

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
in Southern India

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
there's a practice known as jholabhari,

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
in which the pregnant woman, when she's seven or eight months pregnant,

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
moves in with her mother

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and goes through a series of rituals and ceremonies,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
give birth and returns home to her nuclear family

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
several months after the child is born.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
And this is one of many ways

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
that we think other cultures offset this kind of lonely period.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
AV: So taboo number three:

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
you can't talk about your miscarriage -- but today I'll talk about mine.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
So after we had Declan,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
we kind of recalibrated our expectations.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
We thought we actually could go through this again

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
and thought we knew what we would be up against.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
And we were grateful that I was able to get pregnant,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
and I soon learned that we were having a boy,

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
and then when I was five months,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
we learned that we had lost our child.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
This is actually the last little image we have of him.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
And it was obviously a very difficult time --

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
really painful.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
As I was working through that mourning process,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
I was amazed that I didn't want to see anybody.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
I really wanted to crawl into a hole,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
and I didn't really know how I was going

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
to work my way back into my surrounding community.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And I realize, I think, the way I was feeling that way,

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
is on a really deep gut level,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
I was feeling a lot of shame

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
and embarrassed, frankly,

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
that, in some respects, I had failed

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
at delivering what I'm genetically engineered to do.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
And of course, it made me question,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
if I wasn't able to have another child,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
what would that mean for my marriage,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
and just me as a woman.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
So it was a very difficult time.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
As I started working through it more,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
I started climbing out of that hole and talking with other people.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
I was really amazed

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
by all the stories that started flooding in.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
People I interacted with daily,

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
worked with, was friends with,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
family members that I had known a long time,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
had never shared with me their own stories.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And I just remember feeling all these stories came out of the woodwork,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
and I felt like I happened upon

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
this secret society of women that I now was a part of,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
which was reassuring and also really concerning.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
And I think,

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
miscarriage is an invisible loss.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
There's not really a lot of community support around it.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
There's really no ceremony,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
rituals, or rites.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
And I think, with a death, you have a funeral, you celebrate the life,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
and there's a lot of community support,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
and it's something women don't have with miscarriage.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
RG: Which is too bad because, of course,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
it's a very common and very traumatic experience.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
Fifteen to 20 percent of all pregnancies result in miscarriage,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
and I find this astounding.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
In a survey, 74 percent of women said

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
that miscarriage, they felt, was partly their fault, which is awful.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
And astoundingly, 22 percent

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
said they would hide a miscarriage from their spouse.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
So taboo number four:

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
you can't say that your average happiness

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
has declined since having a child.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
The party line is that every single aspect of my life

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
has just gotten dramatically better

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:21.958
ever since I participated

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
in the miracle that is childbirth and family.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
I'll never forget, I remember vividly to this day,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
our first son, Declan, was nine months old,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and I was sitting there on the couch,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
and I was reading Daniel Gilbert's wonderful book, "Stumbling on Happiness."

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
And I got about two-thirds of the way through,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
and there was a chart on the right-hand side --

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
on the right-hand page --

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:45.958
that we've labeled here

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
"The Most Terrifying Chart Imaginable

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
for a New Parent."

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
This chart is comprised of four completely independent studies.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
Basically, there's this precipitous drop

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
of marital satisfaction,

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
which is closely aligned, we all know, with broader happiness,

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
that doesn't rise again

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
until your first child goes to college.

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
So I'm sitting here looking at the next two decades of my life,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
this chasm of happiness

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
that we're driving our proverbial convertible straight into.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
We were despondent.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
AV: So you can imagine, I mean again, the first few months were difficult,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
but we'd come out of it,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
and were really shocked to see this study.

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
So we really wanted to take a deeper look at it

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
in hopes that we would find a silver lining.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
RG: And that's when it's great to be running a website for parents,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
because we got this incredible reporter

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
to go and interview all the scientists

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
who conducted these four studies.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
We said, something is wrong here.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
There's something missing from these studies.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
It can't possibly be that bad.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:48.958
So Liz Mitchell did a wonderful job with this piece,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
and she interviewed four scientists,

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
and she also interviewed Daniel Gilbert,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
and we did indeed find a silver lining.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
So this is our guess

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.958
as to what this baseline of average happiness

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
arguably looks like throughout life.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
Average happiness is, of course, inadequate,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
because it doesn't speak

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
to the moment-by-moment experience,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and so this is what we think it looks like

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
when you layer in

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
moment-to-moment experience.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
And so we all remember as children,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
the tiniest little thing -- and we see it on the faces of our children --

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
the teeniest little thing

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
can just rocket them to these heights

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
of just utter adulation,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
and then the next teeniest little thing

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
can cause them just to plummet to the depths of despair.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
And it's just extraordinary to watch, and we remember it ourselves.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
And then, of course, as you get older,

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
it's almost like age is a form of lithium.

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
As you get older, you become more stable.

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
And part of what happens, I think, in your '20s and '30s,

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
is you start to learn to hedge your happiness.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
You start to realize that

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
"Hey, I could go to this live music event

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
and have an utterly transforming experience

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:56.958
that will cover my entire body with goosebumps,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
but it's more likely that I'll feel claustrophobic

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and I won't be able to get a beer.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
So I'm not going to go.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
I've got a good stereo at home. So, I'm not going to go."

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
So your average happiness goes up,

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
but you lose those transcendent moments.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
AV: Yeah, and then you have your first child,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
and then you really resubmit yourself

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
to these highs and lows --

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
the highs being the first steps, the first smile,

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
your child reading to you for the first time --

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
the lows being, our house, any time from six to seven every night.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
But you realize you resubmit yourself

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
to losing control in a really wonderful way,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
which we think provides a lot of meaning to our lives

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
and is quite gratifying.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
RG: And so in effect,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
we trade average happiness.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
We trade the sort of security and safety

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
of a certain level of contentment

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
for these transcendent moments.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
So where does that leave the two of us

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
as a family with our three little boys

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
in the thick of all this?

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
There's another factor in our case.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
We have violated yet another taboo

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
in our own lives,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
and this is a bonus taboo.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
AV: A quick bonus taboo for you, that we should not be working together,

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
especially with three children --

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
and we are.

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:13.958
RG: And we had reservations about this on the front end.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:16.958
Everybody knows, you should absolutely not work with your spouse.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
In fact, when we first went out to raise money to start Babble,

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
the venture capitalists said,

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
"We categorically don't invest

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
in companies founded by husbands and wives,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
because there's an extra point of failure.

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
It's a bad idea. Don't do it."

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
And we obviously went forward. We did.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
We raised the money, and we're thrilled that we did,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
because in this phase of one's life,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
the incredibly scarce resource is time.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
And if you're really passionate about what you do every day -- which we are --

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
and you're also passionate about your relationship,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
this is the only way we know how to do it.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
And so the final question that we would ask is:

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:52.958
can we collectively bend that happiness chart upwards?

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
It's great that we have these transcendent moments of joy,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
but they're sometimes pretty quick.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
And so how about that average baseline of happiness?

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
Can we move that up a little bit?

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
AV: And we kind of feel that the happiness gap, which we talked about,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
is really the result of walking into parenting --

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
and really any long-term partnership for that matter --

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
with the wrong expectations.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
And if you have the right expectations and expectation management,

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:18.958
we feel like it's going to be a pretty gratifying experience.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
RG: And so this is what --

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:22.958
And we think that a lot of parents,

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
when you get in there -- in our case anyway --

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
you pack your bags for a trip to Europe, and you're really excited to go.

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
Get out of the airplane,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
it turns out you're trekking in Nepal.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
And trekking in Nepal is an extraordinary experience,

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
particularly if you pack your bags properly

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
and you know what you're getting in for and you're psyched.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
So the point of all this for us today

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
is not just hopefully honesty for the sake of honesty,

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
but a hope that by being more honest and candid about these experiences,

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:48.958
that we can all collectively

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:51.958
bend that happiness baseline up a little bit.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
RG + AV: Thank you.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:58.958
(Applause)

title: The case for collaborative consumption
transcript: So today I'm going to talk to you about the rise of collaborative consumption. I'm going to explain what it is and try and convince you — in just 15 minutes — that this isn't a flimsy idea, or a short-term trend, but a powerful cultural and economic force reinventing not just what we consume, but how we consume.Now I'm going to start with a deceptively simple example. Hands up — how many of you have books, CDs, DVDs, or videos lying around your house that you probably won't use again, but you can't quite bring yourself to throw away? Can't see all the hands, but it looks like all of you, right? On our shelves at home, we have a box set of the DVD series "24," season six to be precise. I think it was bought for us around three years ago for a Christmas present. Now my husband, Chris, and I love this show. But let's face it, when you've watched it once maybe, or twice, you don't really want to watch it again, because you know how Jack Bauer is going to defeat the terrorists. So there it sits on our shelves obsolete to us, but with immediate latent value to someone else. Now before we go on, I have a confession to make. I lived in New York for 10 years, and I am a big fan of "Sex and the City." Now I'd love to watch the first movie again as sort of a warm-up to the sequel coming out next week. So how easily could I swap our unwanted copy of "24" for a wanted copy of "Sex and the City?" Now you may have noticed there's a new sector emerging called swap-trading. Now the easiest analogy for swap-trading is like an online dating service for all your unwanted media. What it does is use the Internet to create an infinite marketplace to match person A's "haves" with person C's "wants," whatever they may be.The other week, I went on one of these sites, appropriately called Swaptree, and there were over 59,300 items that I could instantly swap for my copy of "24." Lo and behold, there in Reseda, CA was Rondoron who wanted swap his or her "like new" copy of "Sex and the City" for my copy of "24." So in other words, what's happening here is that Swaptree solves my carrying company's sugar rush problem, a problem the economists call "the coincidence of wants," in approximately 60 seconds. What's even more amazing is it will print out a postage label on the spot, because it knows the way of the item. Now there are layers of technical wonder behind sites such as Swaptree, but that's not my interest, and nor is swap trading, per se.My passion, and what I've spent the last few years dedicated to researching, is the collaborative behaviors and trust-mechanics inherent in these systems. When you think about it, it would have seemed like a crazy idea, even a few years ago, that I would swap my stuff with a total stranger whose real name I didn't know and without any money changing hands. Yet 99 percent of trades on Swaptree happen successfully, and the one percent that receive a negative rating, it's for relatively minor reasons, like the item didn't arrive on time.So what's happening here? An extremely powerful dynamic that has huge commercial and cultural implications is at play. Namely, that technology is enabling trust between strangers. We now live in a global village where we can mimic the ties that used to happen face to face, but on a scale and in ways that have never been possible before. So what's actually happening is that social networks and real-time technologies are taking us back. We're bartering, trading, swapping, sharing, but they're being reinvented into dynamic and appealing forms. What I find fascinating is that we've actually wired our world to share, whether that's our neighborhood, our school, our office, or our Facebook network, and that's creating an economy of "what's mine is yours." From the mighty eBay, the grandfather of exchange marketplaces, to car-sharing companies such as GoGet, where you pay a monthly fee to rent cars by the hour, to social lending platforms such as Zopa, that will take anyone in this audience with 100 dollars to lend, and match them with a borrower anywhere in the world, we're sharing and collaborating again in ways that I believe are more hip than hippie. I call this "groundswell collaborative consumption."Now before I dig into the different systems of collaborative consumption, I'd like to try and answer the question that every author rightfully gets asked, which is, where did this idea come from? Now I'd like to say I woke up one morning and said, "I'm going to write about collaborative consumption," but actually it was a complicated web of seemingly disconnected ideas. Over the next minute, you're going to see a bit like a conceptual fireworks display of all the dots that went on in my head. The first thing I began to notice: how many big concepts were emerging — from the wisdom of crowds to smart mobs — around how ridiculously easy it is to form groups for a purpose. And linked to this crowd mania were examples all around the world — from the election of a president to the infamous Wikipedia, and everything in between — on what the power of numbers could achieve.Now, you know when you learn a new word, and then you start to see that word everywhere? That's what happened to me when I noticed that we are moving from passive consumers to creators, to highly enabled collaborators. What's happening is the Internet is removing the middleman, so that anyone from a T-shirt designer to a knitter can make a living selling peer-to-peer. And the ubiquitous force of this peer-to-peer revolution means that sharing is happening at phenomenal rates. I mean, it's amazing to think that, in every single minute of this speech, 25 hours of YouTube video will be loaded. Now what I find fascinating about these examples is how they're actually tapping into our primate instincts. I mean, we're monkeys, and we're born and bred to share and cooperate. And we were doing so for thousands of years, whether it's when we hunted in packs, or farmed in cooperatives, before this big system called hyper-consumption came along and we built these fences and created out own little fiefdoms. But things are changing, and one of the reasons why is the digital natives, or Gen-Y. They're growing up sharing — files, video games, knowledge. It's second nature to them. So we, the millennials — I am just a millennial — are like foot soldiers, moving us from a culture of "me" to a culture of "we."The reason why it's happening so fast is because of mobile collaboration. We now live in a connected age where we can locate anyone, anytime, in real-time, from a small device in our hands. All of this was going through my head towards the end of 2008, when, of course, the great financial crash happened. Thomas Friedman is one of my favorite New York Times columnists, and he poignantly commented that 2008 is when we hit a wall, when Mother Nature and the market both said, "No more." Now we rationally know that an economy built on hyper-consumption is a Ponzi scheme. It's a house of cards. Yet, it's hard for us to individually know what to do.So all of this is a lot of twittering, right? Well it was a lot of noise and complexity in my head, until actually I realized it was happening because of four key drivers. One, a renewed belief in the importance of community, and a very redefinition of what friend and neighbor really means. A torrent of peer-to-peer social networks and real-time technologies, fundamentally changing the way we behave. Three, pressing unresolved environmental concerns. And four, a global recession that has fundamentally shocked consumer behaviors. These four drivers are fusing together and creating the big shift — away from the 20th century, defined by hyper-consumption, towards the 21st century, defined by collaborative consumption. I generally believe we're at an inflection point where the sharing behaviors — through sites such as Flickr and Twitter that are becoming second nature online — are being applied to offline areas of our everyday lives. From morning commutes to the way fashion is designed to the way we grow food, we are consuming and collaborating once again.So my co-author, Roo Rogers, and I have actually gathered thousands of examples from all around the world of collaborative consumption. And although they vary enormously in scale, maturity and purpose, when we dived into them, we realized that they could actually be organized into three clear systems. The first is redistribution markets. Redistribution markets, just like Swaptree, are when you take a used, or pre-owned, item and move it from where it's not needed to somewhere, or someone, where it is. They're increasingly thought of as the fifth 'R' — reduce, reuse, recycle, repair and redistribute — because they stretch the life cycle of a product and thereby reduce waste.The second is collaborative lifestyles. This is the sharing of resources of things like money, skills and time. I bet, in a couple of years, that phrases like "coworking" and "couchsurfing" and "time banks" are going to become a part of everyday vernacular. One of my favorite examples of collaborative lifestyles is called Landshare. It's a scheme in the U.K. that matches Mr. Jones, with some spare space in his back garden, with Mrs. Smith, a would-be grower. Together they grow their own food. It's one of those ideas that's so simple, yet brilliant, you wonder why it's never been done before.Now, the third system is product-service systems. This is where you pay for the benefit of the product — what it does for you — without needing to own the product outright. This idea is particularly powerful for things that have high-idling capacity. And that can be anything from baby goods to fashions to — how many of you have a power drill, own a power drill? Right. That power drill will be used around 12 to 13 minutes in its entire lifetime. (Laughter) It's kind of ridiculous, right? Because what you need is the hole, not the drill. (Laughter) (Applause) So why don't you rent the drill, or, even better, rent out your own drill to other people and make some money from it? These three systems are coming together, allowing people to share resources without sacrificing their lifestyles, or their cherished personal freedoms. I'm not asking people to share nicely in the sandpit.So I want to just give you an example of how powerful collaborative consumption can be to change behaviors. The average car costs 8,000 dollars a year to run. Yet, that car sits idle for 23 hours a day. So when you consider these two facts, it starts to make a little less sense that we have to own one outright. So this is where car-sharing companies such as Zipcar and GoGet come in. In 2009, Zipcar took 250 participants from across 13 cities — and they're all self-confessed car addicts and car-sharing rookies — and got them to surrender their keys for a month. Instead, these people had to walk, bike, take the train, or other forms of public transport. They could only use their Zipcar membership when absolutely necessary. The results of this challenge after just one month was staggering. It's amazing that 413 lbs were lost just from the extra exercise. But my favorite statistic is that 100 out of the 250 participants did not want their keys back. In other words, the car addicts had lost their urge to own.Now products-service systems have been around for years. Just think of libraries and laundrettes. But I think they're entering a new age, because technology makes sharing frictionless and fun. There's a great quote that was written in the New York Times that said, "Sharing is to ownership what the iPod is to the 8-track, what solar power is to the coal mine." I believe also, our generation, our relationship to satisfying what we want is far less tangible than any other previous generation. I don't want the DVD; I want the movie it carries. I don't want a clunky answering machine; I want the message it saves. I don't want a CD; I want the music it plays. In other words, I don't want stuff; I want the needs or experiences it fulfills. This is fueling a massive shift from where usage trumps possessions — or as Kevin Kelly, the editor of Wired magazine, puts it, "where access is better than ownership."Now as our possessions dematerialize into the cloud, a blurry line is appearing between what's mine, what's yours, and what's ours. I want to give you one example that shows how fast this evolution is happening. This represents an eight-year time span. We've gone from traditional car-ownership to car-sharing companies, such as Zipcar and GoGet, to ride-sharing platforms that match rides to the newest entry, which is peer-to-peer car rental, where you can actually make money out of renting that car that sits idle for 23 hours a day to your neighbor. Now all of these systems require a degree of trust, and the cornerstone to this working is reputation.Now in the old consumer system, our reputation didn't matter so much, because our credit history was far more important that any kind of peer-to-peer review. But now with the Web, we leave a trail. With every spammer we flag, with every idea we post, comment we share, we're actually signaling how well we collaborate, and whether we can or can't be trusted. Let's go back to my first example, Swaptree. I can see that Rondoron has completed 553 trades with a 100 percent success rate. In other words, I can trust him or her. Now mark my words, it's only a matter of time before we're going to be able to perform a Google-like search and see a cumulative picture of our reputation capital. And this reputation capital will determine our access to collaborative consumption. It's a new social currency, so to speak, that could become as powerful as our credit rating.Now as a closing thought, I believe we're actually in a period where we're waking up from this humongous hangover of emptiness and waste, and we're taking a leap to create a more sustainable system built to serve our innate needs for community and individual identity. I believe it will be referred to as a revolution, so to speak — when society, faced with great challenges, made a seismic shift from individual getting and spending towards a rediscovery of collective good. I'm on a mission to make sharing cool. I'm on a mission to make sharing hip. Because I really believe it can disrupt outdated modes of business, help us leapfrog over wasteful forms of hyper-consumption and teach us when enough really is enough.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
