Is there something about me that,
if other people know it or see it,

00:04:48.491 --> 00:04:51.657
that I won't be worthy of connection?

00:04:52.291 --> 00:04:53.973
The things I can tell you about it:

00:04:53.997 --> 00:04:55.664
It's universal; we all have it.

00:04:55.688 --> 00:04:57.688
The only people who don't experience shame

00:04:57.712 --> 00:05:00.046
have no capacity for human
empathy or connection.

00:05:00.070 --> 00:05:01.664
No one wants to talk about it,

00:05:01.688 --> 00:05:04.259
and the less you talk about it,
the more you have it.

00:05:05.703 --> 00:05:10.869
What underpinned this shame,
this "I'm not good enough," --

00:05:10.893 --> 00:05:12.497
which, we all know that feeling:

00:05:12.521 --> 00:05:14.570
"I'm not blank enough.
I'm not thin enough,

00:05:14.594 --> 00:05:17.848
rich enough, beautiful enough,
smart enough, promoted enough."

00:05:17.872 --> 00:05:22.848
The thing that underpinned this
was excruciating vulnerability.

00:05:23.560 --> 00:05:27.664
This idea of, in order
for connection to happen,

00:05:27.688 --> 00:05:31.434
we have to allow ourselves
to be seen, really seen.

00:05:32.759 --> 00:05:35.957
And you know how I feel
about vulnerability. I hate vulnerability.

00:05:35.981 --> 00:05:40.479
And so I thought, this is my chance
to beat it back with my measuring stick.

00:05:40.503 --> 00:05:43.194
I'm going in, I'm going
to figure this stuff out,

00:05:43.218 --> 00:05:46.528
I'm going to spend a year,
I'm going to totally deconstruct shame,

00:05:46.552 --> 00:05:48.830
I'm going to understand
how vulnerability works,

00:05:48.854 --> 00:05:50.289
and I'm going to outsmart it.

00:05:51.338 --> 00:05:53.608
So I was ready, and I was really excited.

00:05:56.937 --> 00:05:59.080
As you know,
it's not going to turn out well.

00:05:59.104 --> 00:06:01.617
(Laughter)

00:06:01.641 --> 00:06:03.235
You know this.

00:06:03.259 --> 00:06:05.148
So, I could tell you a lot about shame,

00:06:05.172 --> 00:06:07.269
but I'd have to borrow
everyone else's time.

00:06:07.293 --> 00:06:10.150
But here's what I can tell you
that it boils down to --

00:06:10.174 --> 00:06:13.556
and this may be one of the most important
things that I've ever learned

00:06:13.580 --> 00:06:15.444
in the decade of doing this research.

00:06:16.766 --> 00:06:20.958
My one year turned into six years:

00:06:20.982 --> 00:06:25.664
Thousands of stories, hundreds
of long interviews, focus groups.

00:06:25.688 --> 00:06:28.069
At one point, people were
sending me journal pages

00:06:28.093 --> 00:06:29.930
and sending me their stories --

00:06:29.954 --> 00:06:33.946
thousands of pieces of data in six years.

00:06:33.970 --> 00:06:35.664
And I kind of got a handle on it.

00:06:35.688 --> 00:06:38.787
I kind of understood, this is
what shame is, this is how it works.

00:06:40.150 --> 00:06:46.397
I wrote a book, I published a theory,
but something was not okay --

00:06:46.421 --> 00:06:50.577
and what it was is that, if I roughly
took the people I interviewed

00:06:50.601 --> 00:06:57.173
and divided them into people who really
have a sense of worthiness --

00:06:57.197 --> 00:06:59.959
that's what this comes down to,
a sense of worthiness --

00:06:59.983 --> 00:07:03.205
they have a strong sense
of love and belonging --

00:07:03.229 --> 00:07:04.880
and folks who struggle for it,

00:07:04.904 --> 00:07:08.004
and folks who are always wondering
if they're good enough.

00:07:08.028 --> 00:07:10.267
There was only one variable that separated

00:07:10.291 --> 00:07:13.031
the people who have a strong sense
of love and belonging

00:07:13.055 --> 00:07:15.314
and the people who really struggle for it.

00:07:15.338 --> 00:07:19.056
And that was, the people who have
a strong sense of love and belonging

00:07:19.080 --> 00:07:21.484
believe they're worthy
of love and belonging.

00:07:22.402 --> 00:07:23.552
That's it.

00:07:24.203 --> 00:07:25.691
They believe they're worthy.

00:07:27.434 --> 00:07:33.252
And to me, the hard part of the one thing
that keeps us out of connection

00:07:33.276 --> 00:07:36.491
is our fear that we're not
worthy of connection,

00:07:36.515 --> 00:07:38.918
was something that,
personally and professionally,

00:07:38.942 --> 00:07:41.164
I felt like I needed to understand better.

00:07:41.505 --> 00:07:46.482
So what I did is I took
all of the interviews

00:07:46.506 --> 00:07:49.324
where I saw worthiness,
where I saw people living that way,

00:07:49.348 --> 00:07:51.236
and just looked at those.

00:07:52.012 --> 00:07:54.060
What do these people have in common?

00:07:54.084 --> 00:07:58.727
I have a slight office supply addiction,
but that's another talk.

00:07:58.751 --> 00:08:02.228
So I had a manila folder,
and I had a Sharpie,

00:08:02.252 --> 00:08:04.872
and I was like, what am I going
to call this research?

00:08:04.896 --> 00:08:07.886
And the first words that came
to my mind were "whole-hearted."

00:08:08.505 --> 00:08:12.021
These are whole-hearted people,
living from this deep sense of worthiness.

00:08:12.045 --> 00:08:14.901
So I wrote at the top
of the manila folder,

00:08:14.925 --> 00:08:16.854
and I started looking at the data.

00:08:16.878 --> 00:08:22.871
In fact, I did it first in a four-day,
very intensive data analysis,

00:08:22.895 --> 00:08:26.472
where I went back, pulled the interviews,
the stories, pulled the incidents.

00:08:26.496 --> 00:08:28.275
What's the theme? What's the pattern?

00:08:29.068 --> 00:08:32.045
My husband left town with the kids

00:08:32.069 --> 00:08:35.046
because I always go into this
Jackson Pollock crazy thing,

00:08:35.070 --> 00:08:38.815
where I'm just writing
and in my researcher mode.

00:08:40.323 --> 00:08:41.870
And so here's what I found.

00:08:44.812 --> 00:08:47.664
What they had in common
was a sense of courage.

00:08:48.322 --> 00:08:51.419
And I want to separate courage
and bravery for you for a minute.

00:08:51.443 --> 00:08:53.884
Courage, the original
definition of courage,

00:08:53.908 --> 00:08:56.147
when it first came
into the English language --

00:08:56.171 --> 00:08:58.524
it's from the Latin word "cor,"
meaning "heart" --

00:08:58.548 --> 00:09:01.559
and the original definition was to tell
the story of who you are

00:09:01.583 --> 00:09:02.997
with your whole heart.

00:09:03.757 --> 00:09:07.931
And so these folks had, very simply,
the courage to be imperfect.

00:09:10.330 --> 00:09:15.307
They had the compassion to be kind
to themselves first and then to others,

00:09:15.331 --> 00:09:16.530
because, as it turns out,

00:09:16.554 --> 00:09:18.788
we can't practice compassion
with other people

00:09:18.812 --> 00:09:20.555
if we can't treat ourselves kindly.

00:09:20.957 --> 00:09:25.354
And the last was they had connection,
and -- this was the hard part --

00:09:25.378 --> 00:09:28.355
as a result of authenticity,

00:09:28.379 --> 00:09:31.664
they were willing to let go
of who they thought they should be

00:09:31.688 --> 00:09:36.292
in order to be who they were,
which you have to absolutely do that

00:09:36.316 --> 00:09:37.489
for connection.

00:09:40.021 --> 00:09:44.021
The other thing that they had
in common was this:

00:09:47.608 --> 00:09:50.688
They fully embraced vulnerability.

00:09:52.377 --> 00:09:59.028
They believed that what made them
vulnerable made them beautiful.

00:10:02.839 --> 00:10:06.664
They didn't talk about vulnerability
being comfortable,

00:10:06.688 --> 00:10:09.514
nor did they really talk
about it being excruciating --

00:10:09.538 --> 00:10:12.016
as I had heard it earlier
in the shame interviewing.

00:10:12.040 --> 00:10:14.270
They just talked about it being necessary.

00:10:15.331 --> 00:10:19.307
They talked about the willingness
to say, "I love you" first ...

00:10:21.076 --> 00:10:26.449
the willingness to do something
where there are no guarantees ...

00:10:27.981 --> 00:10:32.316
the willingness to breathe
through waiting for the doctor to call

00:10:32.340 --> 00:10:33.623
after your mammogram.

00:10:35.329 --> 00:10:38.594
They're willing to invest
in a relationship

00:10:38.618 --> 00:10:40.068
that may or may not work out.

00:10:41.163 --> 00:10:43.033
They thought this was fundamental.

00:10:44.140 --> 00:10:46.759
I personally thought it was betrayal.

00:10:47.545 --> 00:10:52.141
I could not believe I had pledged
allegiance to research, where our job --

00:10:52.165 --> 00:10:56.229
you know, the definition of research
is to control and predict,

00:10:56.253 --> 00:11:00.896
to study phenomena for the explicit
reason to control and predict.

00:11:00.920 --> 00:11:05.286
And now my mission to control and predict

00:11:05.310 --> 00:11:08.879
had turned up the answer
that the way to live is with vulnerability

00:11:08.903 --> 00:11:11.001
and to stop controlling and predicting.

00:11:11.025 --> 00:11:12.802
This led to a little breakdown --

00:11:13.600 --> 00:11:18.664
(Laughter)

00:11:18.688 --> 00:11:21.664
-- which actually looked more like this.

00:11:21.688 --> 00:11:23.181
(Laughter)

00:11:23.205 --> 00:11:25.182
And it did.

00:11:25.206 --> 00:11:28.386
I call it a breakdown; my therapist
calls it a spiritual awakening.

00:11:28.410 --> 00:11:29.644
(Laughter)

00:11:29.668 --> 00:11:32.085
A spiritual awakening
sounds better than breakdown,

00:11:32.109 --> 00:11:33.886
but I assure you, it was a breakdown.

00:11:33.910 --> 00:11:36.814
And I had to put my data away
and go find a therapist.

00:11:36.838 --> 00:11:39.069
Let me tell you something:
you know who you are

00:11:39.093 --> 00:11:42.333
when you call your friends and say,
"I think I need to see somebody.

00:11:42.357 --> 00:11:44.163
Do you have any recommendations?"

00:11:44.187 --> 00:11:46.236
Because about five
of my friends were like,

00:11:46.260 --> 00:11:48.404
"Wooo, I wouldn't want
to be your therapist."

00:11:48.428 --> 00:11:51.166
(Laughter)

00:11:51.190 --> 00:11:53.167
I was like, "What does that mean?"

00:11:53.191 --> 00:11:56.398
And they're like,
"I'm just saying, you know.

00:11:56.422 --> 00:11:58.399
Don't bring your measuring stick."

00:11:58.423 --> 00:12:01.159
(Laughter)

00:12:01.183 --> 00:12:02.383
I was like, "Okay."

00:12:03.243 --> 00:12:05.077
So I found a therapist.

00:12:05.101 --> 00:12:07.004
My first meeting with her, Diana --

00:12:08.807 --> 00:12:13.101
I brought in my list of the way
the whole-hearted live, and I sat down.

00:12:13.125 --> 00:12:14.934
And she said, "How are you?"

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:18.553
And I said, "I'm great. I'm okay."

00:12:18.577 --> 00:12:20.101
She said, "What's going on?"

00:12:20.125 --> 00:12:22.744
And this is a therapist
who sees therapists,

00:12:22.768 --> 00:12:27.981
because we have to go to those,
because their B.S. meters are good.

00:12:28.005 --> 00:12:29.981
(Laughter)

00:12:30.434 --> 00:12:34.267
And so I said, "Here's the thing,
I'm struggling."

00:12:34.291 --> 00:12:36.101
And she said, "What's the struggle?"

00:12:37.140 --> 00:12:39.401
And I said, "Well, I have
a vulnerability issue.

00:12:39.425 --> 00:12:44.780
And I know that vulnerability
is the core of shame and fear

00:12:44.804 --> 00:12:46.401
and our struggle for worthiness,

00:12:46.425 --> 00:12:52.101
but it appears that it's also
the birthplace of joy, of creativity,

00:12:52.125 --> 00:12:54.101
of belonging, of love.

00:12:54.474 --> 00:12:59.910
And I think I have a problem,
and I need some help."

00:12:59.934 --> 00:13:05.101
And I said, "But here's the thing:
no family stuff, no childhood shit."

00:13:05.125 --> 00:13:07.101
(Laughter)

00:13:07.125 --> 00:13:10.101
"I just need some strategies."

00:13:10.125 --> 00:13:14.101
(Laughter)

00:13:14.125 --> 00:13:17.710
(Applause)

00:13:17.734 --> 00:13:19.296
Thank you.

00:13:20.981 --> 00:13:22.458
So she goes like this.

00:13:24.125 --> 00:13:26.481
(Laughter)

00:13:26.505 --> 00:13:29.101
And then I said, "It's bad, right?"

00:13:29.125 --> 00:13:32.101
And she said, "It's neither good nor bad."

00:13:32.125 --> 00:13:33.958
(Laughter)

00:13:33.982 --> 00:13:35.616
"It just is what it is."

00:13:36.362 --> 00:13:39.101
And I said, "Oh my God,
this is going to suck."

00:13:39.125 --> 00:13:41.077
(Laughter)

00:13:42.291 --> 00:13:44.545
And it did, and it didn't.

00:13:44.569 --> 00:13:46.632
And it took about a year.

00:13:46.656 --> 00:13:48.672
And you know how there are people

00:13:48.696 --> 00:13:52.720
that, when they realize that vulnerability
and tenderness are important,

00:13:52.744 --> 00:13:54.775
that they surrender and walk into it.

00:13:55.929 --> 00:13:57.889
A: that's not me,

00:13:57.913 --> 00:14:00.310
and B: I don't even hang out
with people like that.

00:14:00.334 --> 00:14:03.101
(Laughter)

00:14:03.125 --> 00:14:05.212
For me, it was a yearlong street fight.

00:14:06.450 --> 00:14:07.624
It was a slugfest.

00:14:08.037 --> 00:14:09.871
Vulnerability pushed, I pushed back.

00:14:10.291 --> 00:14:13.378
I lost the fight,

00:14:13.402 --> 00:14:15.101
but probably won my life back.

00:14:15.425 --> 00:14:17.401
And so then I went back into the research

00:14:17.425 --> 00:14:19.101
and spent the next couple of years

00:14:19.125 --> 00:14:22.101
really trying to understand
what they, the whole-hearted,

00:14:22.125 --> 00:14:28.101
what choices they were making,
and what we are doing with vulnerability.

00:14:28.125 --> 00:14:30.465
Why do we struggle with it so much?

00:14:30.489 --> 00:14:32.650
Am I alone in struggling
with vulnerability?

00:14:33.888 --> 00:14:35.101
No.

00:14:35.125 --> 00:14:36.586
So this is what I learned.

00:14:38.657 --> 00:14:40.324
We numb vulnerability --

00:14:41.378 --> 00:14:42.965
when we're waiting for the call.

00:14:42.989 --> 00:14:45.878
It was funny, I sent something out
on Twitter and on Facebook

00:14:45.902 --> 00:14:48.176
that says, "How would you
define vulnerability?

00:14:48.200 --> 00:14:49.748
What makes you feel vulnerable?"

00:14:49.772 --> 00:14:52.496
And within an hour and a half,
I had 150 responses.

00:14:52.520 --> 00:14:55.493
Because I wanted to know what's out there.

00:14:57.902 --> 00:15:02.925
Having to ask my husband for help
because I'm sick, and we're newly married;

00:15:02.949 --> 00:15:04.956
initiating sex with my husband;

00:15:04.980 --> 00:15:07.694
initiating sex with my wife;

00:15:07.718 --> 00:15:10.696
being turned down; asking someone out;

00:15:10.720 --> 00:15:12.759
waiting for the doctor to call back;

00:15:12.783 --> 00:15:15.125
getting laid off; laying off people.

00:15:15.149 --> 00:15:16.553
This is the world we live in.

00:15:17.660 --> 00:15:20.628
We live in a vulnerable world.

00:15:20.652 --> 00:15:23.588
And one of the ways we deal
with it is we numb vulnerability.

00:15:24.386 --> 00:15:26.101
And I think there's evidence --

00:15:26.125 --> 00:15:28.506
and it's not the only reason
this evidence exists,

00:15:28.530 --> 00:15:30.639
but I think it's a huge cause --

00:15:30.663 --> 00:15:33.552
We are the most in-debt ...

00:15:35.236 --> 00:15:36.458
obese ...

00:15:37.608 --> 00:15:41.767
addicted and medicated
adult cohort in U.S. history.

00:15:45.013 --> 00:15:48.283
The problem is -- and I learned this
from the research --

00:15:48.307 --> 00:15:51.450
that you cannot selectively numb emotion.

00:15:51.989 --> 00:15:54.322
You can't say, here's the bad stuff.

00:15:55.125 --> 00:15:57.501
Here's vulnerability,
here's grief, here's shame,

00:15:57.525 --> 00:15:59.201
here's fear, here's disappointment.

00:15:59.225 --> 00:16:01.101
I don't want to feel these.

00:16:01.125 --> 00:16:04.007
I'm going to have a couple of beers
and a banana nut muffin.

00:16:04.031 --> 00:16:06.717
(Laughter)

00:16:06.741 --> 00:16:08.610
I don't want to feel these.

00:16:08.634 --> 00:16:10.610
And I know that's knowing laughter.

00:16:10.634 --> 00:16:13.101
I hack into your lives for a living.

00:16:13.125 --> 00:16:15.101
God.

00:16:15.125 --> 00:16:17.672
(Laughter)

00:16:17.696 --> 00:16:20.454
You can't numb those hard feelings

00:16:20.478 --> 00:16:23.112
without numbing
the other affects, our emotions.

00:16:23.136 --> 00:16:24.588
You cannot selectively numb.

00:16:24.612 --> 00:16:27.219
So when we numb those,

00:16:27.243 --> 00:16:29.766
we numb joy,

00:16:29.790 --> 00:16:31.101
we numb gratitude,

00:16:31.125 --> 00:16:32.425
we numb happiness.

00:16:33.846 --> 00:16:36.969
And then, we are miserable,

00:16:36.993 --> 00:16:39.002
and we are looking
for purpose and meaning,

00:16:39.026 --> 00:16:40.458
and then we feel vulnerable,

00:16:40.482 --> 00:16:43.290
so then we have a couple of beers
and a banana nut muffin.

00:16:43.314 --> 00:16:46.680
And it becomes this dangerous cycle.

00:16:47.785 --> 00:16:50.918
One of the things that I think
we need to think about

00:16:50.942 --> 00:16:52.918
is why and how we numb.

00:16:53.626 --> 00:16:55.706
And it doesn't just have to be addiction.

00:16:57.175 --> 00:17:00.548
The other thing we do is we make
everything that's uncertain certain.

00:17:02.125 --> 00:17:07.211
Religion has gone from a belief
in faith and mystery to certainty.

00:17:07.235 --> 00:17:08.917
"I'm right, you're wrong. Shut up."

00:17:10.885 --> 00:17:12.101
That's it.

00:17:13.309 --> 00:17:14.579
Just certain.

00:17:15.038 --> 00:17:17.454
The more afraid we are,
the more vulnerable we are,

00:17:17.478 --> 00:17:18.863
the more afraid we are.

00:17:18.887 --> 00:17:20.894
This is what politics looks like today.

00:17:20.918 --> 00:17:22.593
There's no discourse anymore.

00:17:22.617 --> 00:17:24.101
There's no conversation.

00:17:24.505 --> 00:17:25.729
There's just blame.

00:17:25.753 --> 00:17:28.070
You know how blame
is described in the research?

00:17:29.251 --> 00:17:31.750
A way to discharge pain and discomfort.

00:17:34.314 --> 00:17:35.504
We perfect.

00:17:35.528 --> 00:17:39.306
If there's anyone who wants their life
to look like this, it would be me,

00:17:39.330 --> 00:17:40.557
but it doesn't work.

00:17:40.581 --> 00:17:44.201
Because what we do is we take fat
from our butts and put it in our cheeks.

00:17:44.225 --> 00:17:47.664
(Laughter)

00:17:47.688 --> 00:17:51.101
Which just, I hope in 100 years,
people will look back and go, "Wow."

00:17:51.125 --> 00:17:53.648
(Laughter)

00:17:53.672 --> 00:17:57.101
And we perfect,
most dangerously, our children.

00:17:57.125 --> 00:17:59.268
Let me tell you what we think
about children.

00:17:59.292 --> 00:18:02.101
They're hardwired for struggle
when they get here.

00:18:02.125 --> 00:18:05.007
And when you hold those perfect
little babies in your hand,

00:18:05.031 --> 00:18:07.989
our job is not to say,
"Look at her, she's perfect.

00:18:08.013 --> 00:18:09.909
My job is just to keep her perfect --

00:18:09.933 --> 00:18:13.340
make sure she makes the tennis team
by fifth grade and Yale by seventh."

00:18:13.364 --> 00:18:14.601
That's not our job.

00:18:14.625 --> 00:18:16.234
Our job is to look and say,

00:18:16.258 --> 00:18:19.274
"You know what? You're imperfect,
and you're wired for struggle,

00:18:19.298 --> 00:18:21.298
but you are worthy of love and belonging."

00:18:22.199 --> 00:18:23.386
That's our job.

00:18:23.802 --> 00:18:26.032
Show me a generation
of kids raised like that,

00:18:26.056 --> 00:18:28.657
and we'll end the problems,
I think, that we see today.

00:18:28.681 --> 00:18:34.133
We pretend that what we do
doesn't have an effect on people.

00:18:35.569 --> 00:18:37.203
We do that in our personal lives.

00:18:37.227 --> 00:18:38.450
We do that corporate --

00:18:38.474 --> 00:18:40.584
whether it's a bailout, an oil spill ...

00:18:42.084 --> 00:18:43.244
a recall.

00:18:43.268 --> 00:18:45.245
We pretend like what we're doing

00:18:45.269 --> 00:18:47.355
doesn't have a huge impact
on other people.

00:18:48.125 --> 00:18:51.399
I would say to companies,
this is not our first rodeo, people.

00:18:52.467 --> 00:18:55.134
We just need you to be authentic
and real and say ...

00:18:56.617 --> 00:18:58.761
"We're sorry. We'll fix it."

00:19:02.233 --> 00:19:05.005
But there's another way,
and I'll leave you with this.

00:19:05.029 --> 00:19:06.410
This is what I have found:

00:19:06.434 --> 00:19:10.957
To let ourselves be seen,
deeply seen, vulnerably seen ...

00:19:13.589 --> 00:19:17.978
to love with our whole hearts,
even though there's no guarantee --

00:19:18.002 --> 00:19:19.256
and that's really hard,

00:19:19.280 --> 00:19:22.621
and I can tell you as a parent,
that's excruciatingly difficult --

00:19:25.193 --> 00:19:29.375
to practice gratitude and joy
in those moments of terror,

00:19:29.399 --> 00:19:31.712
when we're wondering,
"Can I love you this much?

00:19:31.736 --> 00:19:33.922
Can I believe in this this passionately?

00:19:33.946 --> 00:19:35.876
Can I be this fierce about this?"

00:19:35.900 --> 00:19:39.477
just to be able to stop and, instead of
catastrophizing what might happen,

00:19:39.501 --> 00:19:41.478
to say, "I'm just so grateful,

00:19:41.502 --> 00:19:43.902
because to feel this vulnerable
means I'm alive."

00:19:45.446 --> 00:19:49.108
And the last, which I think
is probably the most important,

00:19:49.132 --> 00:19:50.782
is to believe that we're enough.

00:19:51.362 --> 00:19:55.211
Because when we work from a place,
I believe, that says, "I'm enough" ...

00:19:57.441 --> 00:20:01.409
then we stop screaming
and start listening,

00:20:01.433 --> 00:20:03.760
we're kinder and gentler
to the people around us,

00:20:03.784 --> 00:20:05.933
and we're kinder and gentler to ourselves.

00:20:06.823 --> 00:20:08.301
That's all I have. Thank you.

00:20:08.325 --> 00:20:10.918
(Applause)

title: Using our practical wisdom
transcript: The first thing I want to do is say thank you to all of you. The second thing I want to do is introduce my co-author and dear friend and co-teacher. Ken and I have been working together for almost 40 years. That's Ken Sharpe over there.(Applause)So there is among many people — certainly me and most of the people I talk to — a kind of collective dissatisfaction with the way things are working, with the way our institutions run. Our kids' teachers seem to be failing them. Our doctors don't know who the hell we are, and they don't have enough time for us. We certainly can't trust the bankers, and we certainly can't trust the brokers. They almost brought the entire financial system down. And even as we do our own work, all too often, we find ourselves having to choose between doing what we think is the right thing and doing the expected thing, or the required thing, or the profitable thing. So everywhere we look, pretty much across the board, we worry that the people we depend on don't really have our interests at heart. Or if they do have our interests at heart, we worry that they don't know us well enough to figure out what they need to do in order to allow us to secure those interests. They don't understand us. They don't have the time to get to know us.There are two kinds of responses that we make to this sort of general dissatisfaction. If things aren't going right, the first response is: let's make more rules, let's set up a set of detailed procedures to make sure that people will do the right thing. Give teachers scripts to follow in the classroom, so even if they don't know what they're doing and don't care about the welfare of our kids, as long as they follow the scripts, our kids will get educated. Give judges a list of mandatory sentences to impose for crimes, so that you don't need to rely on judges using their judgment. Instead, all they have to do is look up on the list what kind of sentence goes with what kind of crime. Impose limits on what credit card companies can charge in interest and on what they can charge in fees. More and more rules to protect us against an indifferent, uncaring set of institutions we have to deal with.Or — or maybe and — in addition to rules, let's see if we can come up with some really clever incentives so that, even if the people we deal with don't particularly want to serve our interests, it is in their interest to serve our interest — the magic incentives that will get people to do the right thing even out of pure selfishness. So we offer teachers bonuses if the kids they teach score passing grades on these big test scores that are used to evaluate the quality of school systems.Rules and incentives — "sticks" and "carrots." We passed a bunch of rules to regulate the financial industry in response to the recent collapse. There's the Dodd-Frank Act, there's the new Consumer Financial Protection Agency that is temporarily being headed through the backdoor by Elizabeth Warren. Maybe these rules will actually improve the way these financial services companies behave. We'll see. In addition, we are struggling to find some way to create incentives for people in the financial services industry that will have them more interested in serving the long-term interests even of their own companies, rather than securing short-term profits. So if we find just the right incentives, they'll do the right thing — as I said — selfishly, and if we come up with the right rules and regulations, they won't drive us all over a cliff. And Ken [Sharpe] and I certainly know that you need to reign in the bankers. If there is a lesson to be learned from the financial collapse it is that.But what we believe, and what we argue in the book, is that there is no set of rules, no matter how detailed, no matter how specific, no matter how carefully monitored and enforced, there is no set of rules that will get us what we need. Why? Because bankers are smart people. And, like water, they will find cracks in any set of rules. You design a set of rules that will make sure that the particular reason why the financial system "almost-collapse" can't happen again. It is naive beyond description to think that having blocked this source of financial collapse, you have blocked all possible sources of financial collapse. So it's just a question of waiting for the next one and then marveling at how we could have been so stupid as not to protect ourselves against that.What we desperately need, beyond, or along with, better rules and reasonably smart incentives, is we need virtue. We need character. We need people who want to do the right thing. And in particular, the virtue that we need most of all is the virtue that Aristotle called "practical wisdom." Practical wisdom is the moral will to do the right thing and the moral skill to figure out what the right thing is. So Aristotle was very interested in watching how the craftsmen around him worked. And he was impressed at how they would improvise novel solutions to novel problems — problems that they hadn't anticipated. So one example is he sees these stonemasons working on the Isle of Lesbos, and they need to measure out round columns. Well if you think about it, it's really hard to measure out round columns using a ruler. So what do they do? They fashion a novel solution to the problem. They created a ruler that bends, what we would call these days a tape measure — a flexible rule, a rule that bends. And Aristotle said, "Hah, they appreciated that sometimes to design rounded columns, you need to bend the rule." And Aristotle said often in dealing with other people, we need to bend the rules.Dealing with other people demands a kind of flexibility that no set of rules can encompass. Wise people know when and how to bend the rules. Wise people know how to improvise. The way my co-author , Ken, and I talk about it, they are kind of like jazz musicians. The rules are like the notes on the page, and that gets you started, but then you dance around the notes on the page, coming up with just the right combination for this particular moment with this particular set of fellow players. So for Aristotle, the kind of rule-bending, rule exception-finding and improvisation that you see in skilled craftsmen is exactly what you need to be a skilled moral craftsman. And in interactions with people, almost all the time, it is this kind of flexibility that is required. A wise person knows when to bend the rules. A wise person knows when to improvise. And most important, a wise person does this improvising and rule-bending in the service of the right aims. If you are a rule-bender and an improviser mostly to serve yourself, what you get is ruthless manipulation of other people. So it matters that you do this wise practice in the service of others and not in the service of yourself. And so the will to do the right thing is just as important as the moral skill of improvisation and exception-finding. Together they comprise practical wisdom, which Aristotle thought was the master virtue.So I'll give you an example of wise practice in action. It's the case of Michael. Michael's a young guy. He had a pretty low-wage job. He was supporting his wife and a child, and the child was going to parochial school. Then he lost his job. He panicked about being able to support his family. One night, he drank a little too much, and he robbed a cab driver — stole 50 dollars. He robbed him at gunpoint. It was a toy gun. He got caught. He got tried. He got convicted. The Pennsylvania sentencing guidelines required a minimum sentence for a crime like this of two years, 24 months. The judge on the case, Judge Lois Forer thought that this made no sense. He had never committed a crime before. He was a responsible husband and father. He had been faced with desperate circumstances. All this would do is wreck a family. And so she improvised a sentence — 11 months, and not only that, but release every day to go to work. Spend your night in jail, spend your day holding down a job. He did. He served out his sentence. He made restitution and found himself a new job. And the family was united.And it seemed on the road to some sort of a decent life — a happy ending to a story involving wise improvisation from a wise judge. But it turned out the prosecutor was not happy that Judge Forer ignored the sentencing guidelines and sort of invented her own, and so he appealed. And he asked for the mandatory minimum sentence for armed robbery. He did after all have a toy gun. The mandatory minimum sentence for armed robbery is five years. He won the appeal. Michael was sentenced to five years in prison. Judge Forer had to follow the law. And by the way, this appeal went through after he had finished serving his sentence, so he was out and working at a job and taking care of his family and he had to go back into jail. Judge Forer did what she was required to do, and then she quit the bench. And Michael disappeared. So that is an example, both of wisdom in practice and the subversion of wisdom by rules that are meant, of course, to make things better.Now consider Ms. Dewey. Ms. Dewey's a teacher in a Texas elementary school. She found herself listening to a consultant one day who was trying to help teachers boost the test scores of the kids, so that the school would reach the elite category in percentage of kids passing big tests. All these schools in Texas compete with one another to achieve these milestones, and there are bonuses and various other treats that come if you beat the other schools. So here was the consultant's advice: first, don't waste your time on kids who are going to pass the test no matter what you do. Second, don't waste your time on kids who can't pass the test no matter what you do. Third, don't waste your time on kids who moved into the district too late for their scores to be counted. Focus all of your time and attention on the kids who are on the bubble, the so-called "bubble kids" — kids where your intervention can get them just maybe over the line from failing to passing. So Ms. Dewey heard this, and she shook her head in despair while fellow teachers were sort of cheering each other on and nodding approvingly. It's like they were about to go play a football game. For Ms. Dewey, this isn't why she became a teacher.Now Ken and I are not naive, and we understand that you need to have rules. You need to have incentives. People have to make a living. But the problem with relying on rules and incentives is that they demoralize professional activity, and they demoralize professional activity in two senses. First, they demoralize the people who are engaged in the activity. Judge Forer quits, and Ms. Dewey in completely disheartened. And second, they demoralize the activity itself. The very practice is demoralized, and the practitioners are demoralized. It creates people — when you manipulate incentives to get people to do the right thing — it creates people who are addicted to incentives. That is to say, it creates people who only do things for incentives.Now the striking thing about this is that psychologists have known this for 30 years. Psychologists have known about the negative consequences of incentivizing everything for 30 years. We know that if you reward kids for drawing pictures, they stop caring about the drawing and care only about the reward. If you reward kids for reading books, they stop caring about what's in the books and only care about how long they are. If you reward teachers for kids' test scores, they stop caring about educating and only care about test preparation. If you were to reward doctors for doing more procedures — which is the current system — they would do more. If instead you reward doctors for doing fewer procedures, they will do fewer. What we want, of course, is doctors who do just the right amount of procedures and do the right amount for the right reason — namely, to serve the welfare of their patients. Psychologists have known this for decades, and it's time for policymakers to start paying attention and listen to psychologists a little bit, instead of economists.And it doesn't have to be this way. We think, Ken and I, that there are real sources of hope. We identify one set of people in all of these practices who we call canny outlaws. These are people who, being forced to operate in a system that demands rule-following and creates incentives, find away around the rules, find a way to subvert the rules. So there are teachers who have these scripts to follow, and they know that if they follow these scripts, the kids will learn nothing. And so what they do is they follow the scripts, but they follow the scripts at double-time and squirrel away little bits of extra time during which they teach in the way that they actually know is effective. So these are little ordinary, everyday heroes, and they're incredibly admirable, but there's no way that they can sustain this kind of activity in the face of a system that either roots them out or grinds them down.So canny outlaws are better than nothing, but it's hard to imagine any canny outlaw sustaining that for an indefinite period of time. More hopeful are people we call system-changers. These are people who are looking not to dodge the system's rules and regulations, but to transform the system, and we talk about several. One in particular is a judge named Robert Russell. And one day he was faced with the case of Gary Pettengill. Pettengill was a 23-year-old vet who had planned to make the army a career, but then he got a severe back injury in Iraq, and that forced him to take a medical discharge. He was married, he had a third kid on the way, he suffered from PTSD, in addition to the bad back, and recurrent nightmares, and he had started using marijuana to ease some of the symptoms. He was only able to get part-time work because of his back, and so he was unable to earn enough to put food on the table and take care of his family. So he started selling marijuana. He was busted in a drug sweep. His family was kicked out of their apartment, and the welfare system was threatening to take away his kids.Under normal sentencing procedures, Judge Russell would have had little choice but to sentence Pettengill to serious jail-time as a drug felon. But Judge Russell did have an alternative. And that's because he was in a special court. He was in a court called the Veterans' Court. In the Veterans' Court — this was the first of its kind in the United States. Judge Russell created the Veterans' Court. It was a court only for veterans who had broken the law. And he had created it exactly because mandatory sentencing laws were taking the judgment out of judging. No one wanted non-violent offenders — and especially non-violent offenders who were veterans to boot — to be thrown into prison. They wanted to do something about what we all know, namely the revolving door of the criminal justice system. And what the Veterans' Court did, was it treated each criminal as an individual, tried to get inside their problems, tried to fashion responses to their crimes that helped them to rehabilitate themselves, and didn't forget about them once the judgment was made. Stayed with them, followed up on them, made sure that they were sticking to whatever plan had been jointly developed to get them over the hump.There are now 22 cities that have Veterans' Courts like this. Why has the idea spread? Well, one reason is that Judge Russell has now seen 108 vets in his Veterans' Court as of February of this year, and out of 108, guess how many have gone back through the revolving door of justice into prison. None. None. Anyone would glom onto a criminal justice system that has this kind of a record. So here's is a system-changer, and it seems to be catching.There's a banker who created a for-profit community bank that encouraged bankers — I know this is hard to believe — encouraged bankers who worked there to do well by doing good for their low-income clients. The bank helped finance the rebuilding of what was otherwise a dying community. Though their loan recipients were high-risk by ordinary standards, the default rate was extremely low. The bank was profitable. The bankers stayed with their loan recipients. They didn't make loans and then sell the loans. They serviced the loans. They made sure that their loan recipients were staying up with their payments. Banking hasn't always been the way we read about it now in the newspapers. Even Goldman Sachs once used to serve clients, before it turned into an institution that serves only itself. Banking wasn't always this way, and it doesn't have to be this way.So there are examples like this in medicine — doctors at Harvard who are trying to transform medical education, so that you don't get a kind of ethical erosion and loss of empathy, which characterizes most medical students in the course of their medical training. And the way they do it is to give third-year medical students patients who they follow for an entire year. So the patients are not organ systems, and they're not diseases; they're people, people with lives. And in order to be an effective doctor, you need to treat people who have lives and not just disease. In addition to which there's an enormous amount of back and forth, mentoring of one student by another, of all the students by the doctors, and the result is a generation — we hope — of doctors who do have time for the people they treat. We'll see.So there are lots of examples like this that we talk about. Each of them shows that it is possible to build on and nurture character and keep a profession true to its proper mission — what Aristotle would have called its proper telos. And Ken and I believe that this is what practitioners actually want. People want to be allowed to be virtuous. They want to have permission to do the right thing. They don't want to feel like they need to take a shower to get the moral grime off their bodies everyday when they come home from work.Aristotle thought that practical wisdom was the key to happiness, and he was right. There's now a lot of research being done in psychology on what makes people happy, and the two things that jump out in study after study — I know this will come as a shock to all of you — the two things that matter most to happiness are love and work. Love: managing successfully relations with the people who are close to you and with the communities of which you are a part. Work: engaging in activities that are meaningful and satisfying. If you have that, good close relations with other people, work that's meaningful and fulfilling, you don't much need anything else.Well, to love well and to work well, you need wisdom. Rules and incentives don't tell you how to be a good friend, how to be a good parent, how to be a good spouse, or how to be a good doctor or a good lawyer or a good teacher. Rules and incentives are no substitutes for wisdom. Indeed, we argue, there is no substitute for wisdom. And so practical wisdom does not require heroic acts of self-sacrifice on the part of practitioners. In giving us the will and the skill to do the right thing — to do right by others — practical wisdom also gives us the will and the skill to do right by ourselves.Thanks.(Applause)

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:41.958
is that there is no set of rules,

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
no matter how detailed,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
no matter how specific,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
no matter how carefully monitored

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
and enforced,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
there is no set of rules

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
that will get us what we need.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Why? Because bankers are smart people.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
And, like water,

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
they will find cracks

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
in any set of rules.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
You design a set of rules that will make sure

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
that the particular reason

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
why the financial system "almost-collapse"

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
can't happen again.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
It is naive beyond description

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
to think that having blocked

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
this source of financial collapse,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:22.958
you have blocked all possible sources of financial collapse.

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
So it's just a question of waiting for the next one

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:28.958
and then marveling at how we could have been so stupid

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
as not to protect ourselves against that.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
What we desperately need,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
beyond, or along with, better rules

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
and reasonably smart incentives,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
is we need virtue.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
We need character.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
We need people who want to do the right thing.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
And in particular,

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
the virtue that we need most of all

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
is the virtue that Aristotle called

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:56.958
"practical wisdom."

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
Practical wisdom

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
is the moral will

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
to do the right thing

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
and the moral skill

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
to figure out what the right thing is.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
So Aristotle was very interested in watching

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
how the craftsmen around him worked.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And he was impressed

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
at how they would improvise

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
novel solutions to novel problems --

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
problems that they hadn't anticipated.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
So one example is he sees these stonemasons

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
working on the Isle of Lesbos,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
and they need to measure out

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
round columns.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
Well if you think about it,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
it's really hard to measure out round columns using a ruler.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
So what do they do?

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
They fashion a novel solution to the problem.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
They created a ruler that bends,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
what we would call these days a tape measure --

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
a flexible rule,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
a rule that bends.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
And Aristotle said,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
"Hah, they appreciated that sometimes

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
to design rounded columns,

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.958
you need to bend the rule."

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
And Aristotle said

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:06.958
often in dealing with other people,

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:09.958
we need to bend the rules.

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
Dealing with other people

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
demands a kind of flexibility

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
that no set of rules can encompass.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
Wise people know when and how

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
to bend the rules.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
Wise people know how to improvise.

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:27.958
The way my co-author , Ken, and I talk about it,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
they are kind of like jazz musicians.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
The rules are like the notes on the page,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
and that gets you started,

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
but then you dance around the notes on the page,

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
coming up with just the right combination

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
for this particular moment

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
with this particular set of fellow players.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
So for Aristotle,

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
the kind

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
of rule-bending,

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
rule exception-finding and improvisation

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
that you see in skilled craftsmen

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
is exactly what you need

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
to be a skilled moral craftsman.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
And in interactions with people,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
almost all the time,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
it is this kind of flexibility that is required.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
A wise person knows when to bend the rules.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
A wise person knows when to improvise.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
And most important,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
a wise person does this improvising and rule-bending

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
in the service of the right aims.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
If you are a rule-bender and an improviser

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
mostly to serve yourself,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
what you get is ruthless manipulation of other people.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
So it matters that you do this wise practice

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
in the service of others

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
and not in the service of yourself.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
And so the will to do the right thing

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
is just as important as the moral skill

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
of improvisation

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and exception-finding.

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
Together they comprise practical wisdom,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
which Aristotle thought

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
was the master virtue.

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
So I'll give you an example

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
of wise practice in action.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
It's the case of Michael.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
Michael's a young guy.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
He had a pretty low-wage job.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
He was supporting his wife and a child,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
and the child was going to parochial school.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
Then he lost his job.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
He panicked

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
about being able to support his family.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
One night, he drank a little too much,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
and he robbed a cab driver --

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
stole 50 dollars.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
He robbed him at gunpoint.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:27.958
It was a toy gun.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:30.958
He got caught. He got tried.

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
He got convicted.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
The Pennsylvania sentencing guidelines

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
required a minimum sentence for a crime like this

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
of two years, 24 months.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:43.958
The judge on the case, Judge Lois Forer

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
thought that this made no sense.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
He had never committed a crime before.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
He was a responsible husband and father.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
He had been faced with desperate circumstances.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
All this would do is wreck a family.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
And so she improvised a sentence -- 11 months,

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
and not only that,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
but release every day to go to work.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
Spend your night in jail, spend your day holding down a job.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
He did. He served out his sentence.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
He made restitution

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
and found himself a new job.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
And the family was united.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
And it seemed on the road

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
to some sort of a decent life --

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:25.958
a happy ending to a story

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
involving wise improvisation

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
from a wise judge.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
But it turned out

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:36.958
the prosecutor was not happy

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:39.958
that Judge Forer ignored the sentencing guidelines

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
and sort of invented her own,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
and so he appealed.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
And he asked for the mandatory minimum sentence

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
for armed robbery.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
He did after all have a toy gun.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
The mandatory minimum sentence for armed robbery

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
is five years.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
He won the appeal.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
Michael was sentenced to five years in prison.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
Judge Forer had to follow the law.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
And by the way, this appeal went through

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
after he had finished serving his sentence,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
so he was out and working at a job

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
and taking care of his family

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and he had to go back into jail.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
Judge Forer did what she was required to do,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
and then she quit the bench.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
And Michael disappeared.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
So that is an example,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
both of wisdom in practice

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
and the subversion of wisdom

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
by rules that are meant, of course, to make things better.

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
Now consider Ms. Dewey.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:43.958
Ms. Dewey's a teacher in a Texas elementary school.

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
She found herself listening to a consultant one day

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
who was trying to help teachers

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
boost the test scores of the kids,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
so that the school

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
would reach the elite category

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
in percentage of kids passing big tests.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:11:59.958
All these schools in Texas compete with one another

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
to achieve these milestones,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
and there are bonuses and various other treats

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
that come if you beat the other schools.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
So here was the consultant's advice:

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
first, don't waste your time on kids

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
who are going to pass the test no matter what you do.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:19.958
Second, don't waste your time

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:22.958
on kids who can't pass the test

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
no matter what you do.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
Third, don't waste your time

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
on kids who moved into the district

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
too late for their scores to be counted.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
Focus all of your time and attention

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
on the kids who are on the bubble,

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
the so-called "bubble kids" --

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
kids where your intervention

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
can get them just maybe over the line

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
from failing to passing.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
So Ms. Dewey heard this,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:51.958
and she shook her head in despair

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:54.958
while fellow teachers were sort of cheering each other on

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
and nodding approvingly.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
It's like they were about to go play a football game.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
For Ms. Dewey,

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
this isn't why she became a teacher.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
Now Ken and I are not naive,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.958
and we understand that you need to have rules.

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
You need to have incentives.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
People have to make a living.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
But the problem

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
with relying on rules and incentives

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
is that they demoralize

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
professional activity,

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
and they demoralize professional activity

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
in two senses.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
First, they demoralize the people

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
who are engaged in the activity.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Judge Forer quits,

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
and Ms. Dewey in completely disheartened.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And second,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
they demoralize the activity itself.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
The very practice is demoralized,

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
and the practitioners are demoralized.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
It creates people --

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
when you manipulate incentives to get people to do the right thing --

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
it creates people

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
who are addicted to incentives.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
That is to say, it creates people

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
who only do things for incentives.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
Now the striking thing about this

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
is that psychologists have known this

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
for 30 years.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
Psychologists have known

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
about the negative consequences of incentivizing everything

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
for 30 years.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
We know that if you reward kids for drawing pictures,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
they stop caring about the drawing

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
and care only about the reward.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
If you reward kids for reading books,

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
they stop caring about what's in the books

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
and only care about how long they are.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
If you reward teachers for kids' test scores,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
they stop caring about educating

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and only care about test preparation.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
If you were to reward doctors

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
for doing more procedures --

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
which is the current system -- they would do more.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
If instead you reward doctors for doing fewer procedures,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
they will do fewer.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
What we want, of course,

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
is doctors who do just the right amount of procedures

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and do the right amount for the right reason --

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
namely, to serve the welfare of their patients.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
Psychologists have known this for decades,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:55.958
and it's time for policymakers

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
to start paying attention

00:14:57.958 --> 00:15:00.958
and listen to psychologists a little bit,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
instead of economists.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
And it doesn't have to be this way.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
We think, Ken and I, that there are real sources of hope.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:10.958
We identify one set of people

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
in all of these practices

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
who we call canny outlaws.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
These are people

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
who, being forced to operate

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
in a system that demands rule-following

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and creates incentives,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
find away around the rules,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
find a way to subvert the rules.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
So there are teachers who have these scripts to follow,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:33.958
and they know that if they follow these scripts, the kids will learn nothing.

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:36.958
And so what they do is they follow the scripts,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
but they follow the scripts at double-time

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
and squirrel away little bits of extra time

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
during which they teach in the way

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:47.958
that they actually know is effective.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:50.958
So these are little ordinary, everyday heroes,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
and they're incredibly admirable,

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
but there's no way that they can sustain this kind of activity

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
in the face of a system

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
that either roots them out

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
or grinds them down.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
So canny outlaws are better than nothing,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
but it's hard to imagine any canny outlaw

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:08.958
sustaining that for an indefinite period of time.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
More hopeful

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
are people we call system-changers.

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
These are people who are looking

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
not to dodge the system's rules and regulations,

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
but to transform the system,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
and we talk about several.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
One in particular

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:26.958
is a judge named Robert Russell.

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:28.958
And one day he was faced

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
with the case of Gary Pettengill.

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
Pettengill was a 23-year-old vet

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:36.958
who had planned to make the army a career,

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
but then he got a severe back injury in Iraq,

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
and that forced him to take a medical discharge.

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
He was married, he had a third kid on the way,

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
he suffered from PTSD, in addition to the bad back,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
and recurrent nightmares,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
and he had started using marijuana

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
to ease some of the symptoms.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
He was only able to get part-time work because of his back,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
and so he was unable to earn enough to put food on the table

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
and take care of his family.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
So he started selling marijuana.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
He was busted in a drug sweep.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
His family was kicked out of their apartment,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
and the welfare system

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
was threatening to take away his kids.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:15.958
Under normal sentencing procedures,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:18.958
Judge Russell would have had little choice

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
but to sentence Pettengill to serious jail-time

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
as a drug felon.

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
But Judge Russell did have an alternative.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
And that's because he was in a special court.

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
He was in a court called the Veterans' Court.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
In the Veterans' Court --

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
this was the first of its kind in the United States.

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
Judge Russell created the Veterans' Court.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:41.958
It was a court only for veterans

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
who had broken the law.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:46.958
And he had created it exactly because

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:48.958
mandatory sentencing laws

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:51.958
were taking the judgment out of judging.

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:54.958
No one wanted non-violent offenders --

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
and especially non-violent offenders who were veterans to boot --

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
to be thrown into prison.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:02.958
They wanted to do something about what we all know,

00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:05.958
namely the revolving door of the criminal justice system.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:07.958
And what the Veterans' Court did,

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:10.958
was it treated each criminal as an individual,

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
tried to get inside their problems,

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:16.958
tried to fashion responses to their crimes

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
that helped them to rehabilitate themselves,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:21.958
and didn't forget about them once the judgment was made.

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:24.958
Stayed with them, followed up on them,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
made sure that they were sticking to whatever plan

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
had been jointly developed

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
to get them over the hump.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
There are now 22 cities

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:34.958
that have Veterans' Courts like this.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
Why has the idea spread?

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:39.958
Well, one reason is

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:41.958
that Judge Russell

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
has now seen 108 vets

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
in his Veterans' Court

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
as of February of this year,

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
and out of 108,

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:51.958
guess how many have gone back through

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:53.958
the revolving door of justice

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:55.958
into prison.

00:18:55.958 --> 00:18:57.958
None. None.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:19:00.958
Anyone would glom onto

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:02.958
a criminal justice system

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:04.958
that has this kind of a record.

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:07.958
So here's is a system-changer, and it seems to be catching.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
There's a banker

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:11.958
who created a for-profit community bank

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:14.958
that encouraged bankers -- I know this is hard to believe --

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:17.958
encouraged bankers who worked there to do well

00:19:17.958 --> 00:19:20.958
by doing good for their low-income clients.

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:23.958
The bank helped finance the rebuilding

00:19:23.958 --> 00:19:26.958
of what was otherwise a dying community.

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:29.958
Though their loan recipients were high-risk by ordinary standards,

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:32.958
the default rate was extremely low.

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:35.958
The bank was profitable.

00:19:35.958 --> 00:19:37.958
The bankers stayed with their loan recipients.

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.958
They didn't make loans and then sell the loans.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
They serviced the loans.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:43.958
They made sure that their loan recipients

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:46.958
were staying up with their payments.

00:19:46.958 --> 00:19:49.958
Banking hasn't always been

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:53.958
the way we read about it now in the newspapers.

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:55.958
Even Goldman Sachs

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:58.958
once used to serve clients,

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:01.958
before it turned into an institution

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:03.958
that serves only itself.

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:05.958
Banking wasn't always this way,

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:08.958
and it doesn't have to be this way.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.958
So there are examples like this in medicine --

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:15.958
doctors at Harvard

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:17.958
who are trying to transform medical education,

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:19.958
so that you don't get a kind of ethical erosion

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:21.958
and loss of empathy,

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:23.958
which characterizes most medical students

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:25.958
in the course of their medical training.

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:28.958
And the way they do it is to give third-year medical students

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:30.958
patients who they follow for an entire year.

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:32.958
So the patients are not organ systems,

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:34.958
and they're not diseases;

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:36.958
they're people, people with lives.

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:38.958
And in order to be an effective doctor,

00:20:38.958 --> 00:20:41.958
you need to treat people who have lives and not just disease.

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:44.958
In addition to which there's an enormous amount of back and forth,

00:20:44.958 --> 00:20:46.958
mentoring of one student by another,

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:49.958
of all the students by the doctors,

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:52.958
and the result is a generation -- we hope -- of doctors

00:20:52.958 --> 00:20:54.958
who do have time for the people they treat.

00:20:54.958 --> 00:20:56.958
We'll see.

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:59.958
So there are lots of examples like this that we talk about.

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:01.958
Each of them shows that it is possible

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:04.958
to build on and nurture character

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:06.958
and keep a profession

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:08.958
true to its proper mission --

00:21:08.958 --> 00:21:11.958
what Aristotle would have called its proper telos.

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:14.958
And Ken and I believe

00:21:14.958 --> 00:21:17.958
that this is what practitioners actually want.

00:21:17.958 --> 00:21:19.958
People want to be allowed

00:21:19.958 --> 00:21:21.958
to be virtuous.

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:24.958
They want to have permission to do the right thing.

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:26.958
They don't want to feel

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:28.958
like they need to take a shower

00:21:28.958 --> 00:21:31.958
to get the moral grime off their bodies everyday

00:21:31.958 --> 00:21:34.958
when they come home from work.

00:21:34.958 --> 00:21:36.958
Aristotle thought that practical wisdom

00:21:36.958 --> 00:21:38.958
was the key to happiness,

00:21:38.958 --> 00:21:41.958
and he was right.

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:44.958
There's now a lot of research being done in psychology

00:21:44.958 --> 00:21:46.958
on what makes people happy,

00:21:46.958 --> 00:21:49.958
and the two things that jump out in study after study --

00:21:49.958 --> 00:21:51.958
I know this will come as a shock to all of you --

00:21:51.958 --> 00:21:54.958
the two things that matter most to happiness

00:21:54.958 --> 00:21:57.958
are love and work.

00:21:57.958 --> 00:22:00.958
Love: managing successfully

00:22:00.958 --> 00:22:02.958
relations with the people who are close to you

00:22:02.958 --> 00:22:05.958
and with the communities of which you are a part.

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:08.958
Work: engaging in activities

00:22:08.958 --> 00:22:11.958
that are meaningful and satisfying.

00:22:11.958 --> 00:22:14.958
If you have that, good close relations with other people,

00:22:14.958 --> 00:22:17.958
work that's meaningful and fulfilling,

00:22:17.958 --> 00:22:20.958
you don't much need anything else.

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:23.958
Well, to love well and to work well,

00:22:23.958 --> 00:22:25.958
you need wisdom.

00:22:25.958 --> 00:22:27.958
Rules and incentives don't tell you

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:30.958
how to be a good friend, how to be a good parent,

00:22:30.958 --> 00:22:32.958
how to be a good spouse,

00:22:32.958 --> 00:22:34.958
or how to be a good doctor or a good lawyer

00:22:34.958 --> 00:22:36.958
or a good teacher.

00:22:36.958 --> 00:22:38.958
Rules and incentives

00:22:38.958 --> 00:22:40.958
are no substitutes for wisdom.

00:22:40.958 --> 00:22:42.958
Indeed, we argue,

00:22:42.958 --> 00:22:45.958
there is no substitute for wisdom.

00:22:45.958 --> 00:22:47.958
And so practical wisdom

00:22:47.958 --> 00:22:49.958
does not require

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:52.958
heroic acts of self-sacrifice

00:22:52.958 --> 00:22:55.958
on the part of practitioners.

00:22:55.958 --> 00:22:57.958
In giving us the will and the skill

00:22:57.958 --> 00:23:00.958
to do the right thing -- to do right by others --

00:23:00.958 --> 00:23:02.958
practical wisdom also gives us

00:23:02.958 --> 00:23:04.958
the will and the skill

00:23:04.958 --> 00:23:07.958
to do right by ourselves.

00:23:07.958 --> 00:23:09.958
Thanks.

00:23:09.958 --> 00:23:12.958
(Applause)

title: How to succeed? Get more sleep
transcript: My big idea is a very, very small idea that can unlock billions of big ideas that are at the moment dormant inside us. And my little idea that will do that is sleep.(Laughter)(Applause)This is a room of type A women. This is a room of sleep-deprived women. And I learned the hard way the value of sleep. Two-and-a-half years ago, I fainted from exhaustion. I hit my head on my desk. I broke my cheekbone, I got five stitches on my right eye. And I began the journey of rediscovering the value of sleep. And in the course of that, I studied, I met with medical doctors, scientists, and I'm here to tell you that the way to a more productive, more inspired, more joyful life is getting enough sleep.(Applause)And we women are going to lead the way in this new revolution, this new feminist issue. We are literally going to sleep our way to the top — literally —(Laughter)(Applause)because unfortunately, for men, sleep deprivation has become a virility symbol. I was recently having dinner with a guy who bragged that he had only gotten four hours sleep the night before. And I felt like saying to him — but I didn't say — I felt like saying, "You know what? if you had gotten five, this dinner would have been a lot more interesting."(Laughter)There is now a kind of sleep deprivation one-upmanship. Especially here in Washington, if you try to make a breakfast date, and you say, "How about eight o'clock?" they're likely to tell you, "Eight o'clock is too late for me, but that's OK, I can get a game of tennis in and do a few conference calls and meet you at eight." And they think that means they are so incredibly busy and productive, but the truth is, they're not, because we, at the moment, have had brilliant leaders in business, in finance, in politics, making terrible decisions. So a high IQ does not mean that you're a good leader, because the essence of leadership is being able to see the iceberg before it hits the Titanic.(Laughter)And we've had far too many icebergs hitting our Titanics. In fact, I have a feeling that if Lehman Brothers was Lehman Brothers and Sisters, they might still be around.(Laughter)(Applause)While all the brothers were busy just being hyper-connected 24/7, maybe a sister would have noticed the iceberg, because she would have woken up from a seven-and-a-half- or eight-hour sleep, and have been able to see the big picture.So as we are facing all the multiple crises in our world at the moment, what is good for us on a personal level, what's going to bring more joy, gratitude, effectiveness in our lives and be the best for our own careers, is also what is best for the world. So I urge you to shut your eyes, and discover the great ideas that lie inside us; to shut your engines and discover the power of sleep.Thank you.(Applause)
