in an overcrowded school.

00:01:54.207 --> 00:01:56.328
And if you are a boy,

00:01:56.352 --> 00:02:00.088
you're four times as likely
to be diagnosed with ADHD --

00:02:00.112 --> 00:02:02.573
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder.

00:02:03.037 --> 00:02:06.098
Now there is another side to this.

00:02:06.122 --> 00:02:11.732
And it is important that we recognize
that women still need help in school,

00:02:11.756 --> 00:02:14.019
that salaries are still
significantly lower,

00:02:14.043 --> 00:02:16.341
even when controlled for job types,

00:02:16.365 --> 00:02:20.100
and that girls have continued to struggle
in math and science for years.

00:02:20.672 --> 00:02:21.828
That's all true.

00:02:21.852 --> 00:02:24.131
Nothing about that prevents us

00:02:24.155 --> 00:02:26.189
from paying attention
to the literacy needs

00:02:26.213 --> 00:02:28.284
of our boys between ages three and 13.

00:02:28.807 --> 00:02:29.959
And so we should.

00:02:29.983 --> 00:02:33.006
In fact, what we ought to do
is take a page from their playbook,

00:02:33.030 --> 00:02:37.277
because the initiatives and programs
that have been set in place

00:02:37.301 --> 00:02:41.142
for women in science and engineering
and mathematics are fantastic.

00:02:41.166 --> 00:02:45.096
They've done a lot of good
for girls in these situations,

00:02:45.120 --> 00:02:48.934
and we ought to be thinking about
how we can make that happen for boys too

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.235
in their younger years.

00:02:51.058 --> 00:02:52.934
Even in their older years,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.445
what we find is that
there's still a problem.

00:02:55.469 --> 00:02:57.054
When we look at the universities,

00:02:57.078 --> 00:03:00.076
60 percent of baccalaureate degrees
are going to women now,

00:03:00.100 --> 00:03:01.934
which is a significant shift.

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:05.829
And in fact, university administrators
are a little uncomfortable about the idea

00:03:05.853 --> 00:03:10.758
that we may be getting close to 70 percent
female population in universities.

00:03:10.782 --> 00:03:13.132
This makes university
administrators very nervous,

00:03:13.156 --> 00:03:16.346
because girls don't want to go
to schools that don't have boys.

00:03:18.488 --> 00:03:20.586
And so we're starting to see

00:03:20.610 --> 00:03:23.767
the establishment of men centers
and men studies

00:03:23.791 --> 00:03:28.068
to think about how do we engage men
in their experiences in the university.

00:03:28.092 --> 00:03:30.869
If you talk to faculty,
they may say, "Ugh. Yeah, well,

00:03:30.893 --> 00:03:32.441
they're playing video games,

00:03:32.465 --> 00:03:35.434
and they're gambling
online all night long,

00:03:35.458 --> 00:03:37.273
and they're playing World of Warcraft,

00:03:37.297 --> 00:03:41.129
and that's affecting
their academic achievement."

00:03:42.418 --> 00:03:43.599
Guess what?

00:03:43.623 --> 00:03:46.094
Video games are not the cause.

00:03:46.118 --> 00:03:47.933
Video games are a symptom.

00:03:48.439 --> 00:03:52.839
They were turned off a long time
before they got here.

00:03:53.085 --> 00:03:55.744
So let's talk about
why they got turned off

00:03:55.768 --> 00:03:58.617
when they were between the ages
of three and 13.

00:03:59.148 --> 00:04:01.027
There are three reasons that I believe

00:04:01.051 --> 00:04:04.313
that boys are out of sync
with the culture of schools today.

00:04:04.712 --> 00:04:06.934
The first is zero tolerance.

00:04:07.325 --> 00:04:12.342
A kindergarten teacher I know,
her son donated all of his toys to her,

00:04:12.366 --> 00:04:18.212
and when he did, she had to go through
and pull out all the little plastic guns.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.452
You can't have plastic knives
and swords and axes

00:04:21.476 --> 00:04:24.619
and all that kind of thing
in a kindergarten classroom.

00:04:24.643 --> 00:04:28.518
What is it that we're afraid that this
young man is going to do with this gun?

00:04:28.542 --> 00:04:29.934
I mean, really.

00:04:30.616 --> 00:04:32.934
But here he stands as testament

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:36.234
to the fact that you can't roughhouse
on the playground today.

00:04:36.258 --> 00:04:38.267
Now I'm not advocating for bullies.

00:04:38.291 --> 00:04:43.494
I'm not suggesting that we need to be
allowing guns and knives in the school.

00:04:43.518 --> 00:04:47.774
But when we say that an Eagle Scout
in a high school classroom

00:04:47.798 --> 00:04:51.123
who has a locked parked car
in the parking lot and a penknife in it,

00:04:51.147 --> 00:04:53.170
has to be suspended from school,

00:04:53.194 --> 00:04:56.494
I think we may have gone
a little too far with zero tolerance.

00:04:56.518 --> 00:04:58.846
Another way that zero tolerance
lives itself out

00:04:58.870 --> 00:05:00.161
is in the writing of boys.

00:05:00.185 --> 00:05:01.570
In a lot of classrooms today,

00:05:01.594 --> 00:05:04.314
you're not allowed to write
about anything that's violent.

00:05:04.338 --> 00:05:07.864
You're not allowed to write about anything
that has to do with video games.

00:05:07.888 --> 00:05:09.058
These topics are banned.

00:05:09.082 --> 00:05:11.030
Boy comes home from school, and he says,

00:05:11.054 --> 00:05:12.504
"I hate writing."

00:05:12.528 --> 00:05:15.255
"Why do you hate writing, son?
What's wrong with writing?"

00:05:15.279 --> 00:05:17.592
"Now I have to write
what she tells me to write."

00:05:17.616 --> 00:05:19.617
"OK, what is she telling you to write?"

00:05:20.061 --> 00:05:22.422
"Poems. I have to write poems.

00:05:22.446 --> 00:05:24.442
And little moments in my life.

00:05:24.466 --> 00:05:26.442
I don't want to write that stuff."

00:05:26.838 --> 00:05:28.480
"Well, what do you want to write?

00:05:28.504 --> 00:05:30.095
What do you want to write about?"

00:05:30.119 --> 00:05:33.408
"I want to write about video games.
I want to write about leveling-up.

00:05:33.432 --> 00:05:35.870
I want to write about
this really interesting world.

00:05:35.894 --> 00:05:38.723
I want to write about a tornado
that comes into our house

00:05:38.747 --> 00:05:40.259
and blows all the windows out,

00:05:40.283 --> 00:05:42.589
and ruins all the furniture
and kills everybody."

00:05:42.613 --> 00:05:44.084
"All right. OK."

00:05:44.108 --> 00:05:47.831
You tell a teacher that,
and they'll ask you, in all seriousness,

00:05:47.855 --> 00:05:50.531
"Should we send this child
to the psychologist?"

00:05:51.575 --> 00:05:53.934
And the answer is no, he's just a boy.

00:05:54.470 --> 00:05:56.261
He's just a little boy.

00:05:57.134 --> 00:06:00.933
It's not OK to write these kinds of things
in classrooms today.

00:06:01.792 --> 00:06:03.087
So that's the first reason:

00:06:03.111 --> 00:06:05.660
Zero tolerance policies
and the way they're lived out.

00:06:05.684 --> 00:06:09.165
The next reason that boys' cultures
are out of sync with school cultures:

00:06:09.189 --> 00:06:10.626
there are fewer male teachers.

00:06:10.650 --> 00:06:13.409
Anybody who's over 15
doesn't know what this means,

00:06:13.433 --> 00:06:15.189
because in the last 10 years,

00:06:15.213 --> 00:06:19.006
the number of elementary school
classroom teachers has been cut in half.

00:06:19.030 --> 00:06:22.422
We went from 14 percent to seven percent.

00:06:22.898 --> 00:06:25.221
That means that 93 percent of the teachers

00:06:25.245 --> 00:06:28.364
that our young men get in elementary
classrooms are women.

00:06:29.441 --> 00:06:31.342
Now what's the problem with this?

00:06:31.695 --> 00:06:33.592
Women are great, yep, absolutely.

00:06:34.298 --> 00:06:38.740
But male role models for boys
that say it's all right to be smart --

00:06:38.764 --> 00:06:42.366
they've got dads, they've got pastors,
they've got Cub Scout leaders,

00:06:42.390 --> 00:06:45.474
but ultimately, six hours a day,
five days a week

00:06:45.498 --> 00:06:47.744
they're spending in a classroom,

00:06:47.768 --> 00:06:51.132
and most of those classrooms
are not places where men exist.

00:06:51.156 --> 00:06:54.704
And so they say, I guess this really
isn't a place for boys.

00:06:55.081 --> 00:06:56.749
This is a place for girls.

00:06:56.773 --> 00:06:58.363
And I'm not very good at this,

00:06:58.387 --> 00:07:01.595
so I guess I'd better go play video games

00:07:01.619 --> 00:07:03.630
or get into sports,
or something like that,

00:07:03.654 --> 00:07:05.536
because I obviously don't belong here.

00:07:05.560 --> 00:07:07.670
Men don't belong here,
that's pretty obvious.

00:07:07.694 --> 00:07:11.582
So that may be a very direct way
that we see it happen.

00:07:12.030 --> 00:07:15.933
But less directly, the lack of male
presence in the culture --

00:07:16.455 --> 00:07:19.645
you've got a teachers' lounge,
and they're having a conversation

00:07:19.669 --> 00:07:23.796
about Joey and Johnny
who beat each other up on the playground.

00:07:23.820 --> 00:07:25.824
"What are we going to do with these boys?"

00:07:25.848 --> 00:07:27.532
The answer to that question changes

00:07:27.556 --> 00:07:29.657
depending on who's sitting
around that table.

00:07:29.681 --> 00:07:31.241
Are there men around that table?

00:07:31.265 --> 00:07:33.715
Are there moms who've raised boys
around that table?

00:07:33.739 --> 00:07:35.481
You'll see, the conversation changes

00:07:35.505 --> 00:07:37.653
depending upon who's sitting
around the table.

00:07:37.677 --> 00:07:40.529
Third reason that boys
are out of sync with school today:

00:07:40.553 --> 00:07:42.997
Kindergarten is the old
second grade, folks.

00:07:43.021 --> 00:07:46.933
We have a serious compression
of the curriculum happening out there.

00:07:47.290 --> 00:07:50.383
When you're three, you better be able
to write your name legibly,

00:07:50.407 --> 00:07:52.984
or else we'll consider it
a developmental delay.

00:07:53.452 --> 00:07:55.095
By the time you're in first grade,

00:07:55.119 --> 00:07:57.724
you should be able to read
paragraphs of text

00:07:57.748 --> 00:08:01.228
with maybe a picture, maybe not,
in a book of maybe 25 to 30 pages.

00:08:01.252 --> 00:08:02.432
If you don't,

00:08:02.456 --> 00:08:06.131
we're probably going to be putting you
into a Title I special reading program.

00:08:06.155 --> 00:08:08.453
And if you ask Title I teachers,
they'll tell you

00:08:08.477 --> 00:08:12.096
they've got about four or five boys
for every girl that's in their program,

00:08:12.120 --> 00:08:13.324
in the elementary grades.

00:08:13.348 --> 00:08:15.102
The reason that this is a problem

00:08:15.126 --> 00:08:18.179
is because the message
that boys are getting

00:08:18.203 --> 00:08:22.545
is, "You need to do what the teacher
asks you to do all the time."

00:08:23.050 --> 00:08:27.210
The teacher's salary depends
on "No Child Left Behind"

00:08:27.234 --> 00:08:29.934
and "Race to the Top"
and accountability and testing

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.934
and all of this.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:35.932
So she has to figure out a way
to get all these boys

00:08:35.956 --> 00:08:38.933
through this curriculum -- and girls.

00:08:39.840 --> 00:08:43.419
This compressed curriculum is bad
for all active kids.

00:08:44.444 --> 00:08:46.264
And what happens is,

00:08:46.288 --> 00:08:50.948
she says, "Please, sit down,
be quiet, do what you're told,

00:08:50.972 --> 00:08:55.924
follow the rules, manage your time,
focus, be a girl."

00:08:57.267 --> 00:08:58.825
That's what she tells them.

00:08:58.849 --> 00:09:00.934
Indirectly, that's what she tells them.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.018
And so this is a very serious problem.

00:09:03.042 --> 00:09:05.399
Where is it coming from?
It's coming from us.

00:09:05.423 --> 00:09:07.934
(Laughter)

00:09:08.690 --> 00:09:11.658
We want our babies to read
when they are six months old.

00:09:11.682 --> 00:09:12.934
Have you seen the ads?

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:17.638
We want to live in Lake Wobegon
where every child is above average ...

00:09:18.356 --> 00:09:21.800
but what this does to our children
is really not healthy.

00:09:21.824 --> 00:09:23.634
It's not developmentally appropriate,

00:09:23.658 --> 00:09:25.634
and it's particularly bad for boys.

00:09:26.102 --> 00:09:27.377
So what do we do?

00:09:27.858 --> 00:09:29.583
We need to meet them where they are.

00:09:29.607 --> 00:09:31.871
We need to put ourselves into boy culture.

00:09:31.895 --> 00:09:37.150
We need to change the mindset
of acceptance in boys

00:09:37.174 --> 00:09:38.612
in elementary schools.

00:09:39.126 --> 00:09:42.322
More specifically, we can do
some very specific things.

00:09:42.346 --> 00:09:43.934
We can design better games.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.773
Most of the educational games
that are out there today

00:09:46.797 --> 00:09:48.322
are really flashcards.

00:09:48.346 --> 00:09:50.288
They're glorified drill and practice.

00:09:50.312 --> 00:09:53.125
They don't have the depth,
the rich narrative

00:09:53.149 --> 00:09:55.901
that really engaging video games have,

00:09:55.925 --> 00:09:57.928
that the boys are really interested in.

00:09:57.952 --> 00:09:59.594
So we need to design better games.

00:09:59.618 --> 00:10:03.444
We need to talk to teachers and parents
and school board members and politicians.

00:10:03.468 --> 00:10:07.044
We need to make sure that people see
that we need more men in the classroom.

00:10:07.068 --> 00:10:09.762
We need to look carefully
at our zero tolerance policies.

00:10:09.786 --> 00:10:10.954
Do they make sense?

00:10:10.978 --> 00:10:14.934
We need to think about how to uncompress
this curriculum if we can,

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:18.423
trying to bring boys back into a space
that is comfortable for them.

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.244
All of those conversations
need to be happening.

00:10:21.268 --> 00:10:24.071
There are some great examples
out there of schools --

00:10:24.095 --> 00:10:27.578
the New York Times
just talked about a school recently.

00:10:27.602 --> 00:10:29.934
A game designer from the New School

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.934
put together a wonderful
video gaming school.

00:10:33.350 --> 00:10:38.187
But it only treats a few kids,
and so this isn't very scalable.

00:10:38.211 --> 00:10:40.367
We have to change the culture
and the feelings

00:10:40.391 --> 00:10:45.213
that politicians and school board
members and parents have

00:10:45.237 --> 00:10:48.304
about the way we accept
and what we accept in our schools today.

00:10:48.328 --> 00:10:50.337
We need to find more money
for game design.

00:10:50.361 --> 00:10:52.715
Because good games,
really good games, cost money,

00:10:52.739 --> 00:10:54.726
and World of Warcraft has quite a budget.

00:10:54.750 --> 00:10:56.842
Most of the educational games do not.

00:10:56.866 --> 00:10:58.114
Where we started:

00:10:58.138 --> 00:11:00.934
my colleagues Mike Petner,
Shawn Vashaw, myself,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.549
we started by trying to look
at the teachers' attitudes

00:11:03.573 --> 00:11:05.918
and find out how do they really
feel about gaming,

00:11:05.942 --> 00:11:07.202
what do they say about it.

00:11:07.226 --> 00:11:12.200
And we discovered that they talk
about the kids in their school,

00:11:12.224 --> 00:11:14.933
who talk about gaming,
in pretty demeaning ways.

00:11:15.490 --> 00:11:18.683
They say, "Oh, yeah. They're always
talking about that stuff.

00:11:18.707 --> 00:11:21.031
They're talking
about their little action figures

00:11:21.055 --> 00:11:23.443
and their little achievements
or merit badges,

00:11:23.467 --> 00:11:25.525
or whatever it is that they get.

00:11:25.549 --> 00:11:27.651
And they're always talking
about this stuff."

00:11:27.675 --> 00:11:29.632
And they say these things as if it's OK.

00:11:29.656 --> 00:11:32.934
But if it were your culture,
think of how that might feel.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.339
It's very uncomfortable
to be on the receiving end

00:11:35.363 --> 00:11:37.545
of that kind of language.

00:11:37.934 --> 00:11:41.150
They're nervous about anything
that has anything to do with violence

00:11:41.174 --> 00:11:43.059
because of the zero tolerance policies.

00:11:43.083 --> 00:11:45.194
They are sure that parents
and administrators

00:11:45.218 --> 00:11:46.516
will never accept anything.

00:11:46.540 --> 00:11:49.424
So we really need to think
about looking at teacher attitudes

00:11:49.448 --> 00:11:52.210
and finding ways to change the attitudes,

00:11:52.234 --> 00:11:56.204
so that teachers are much more open
and accepting of boy cultures

00:11:56.228 --> 00:11:57.418
in their classrooms.

00:11:57.442 --> 00:11:59.510
Because, ultimately, if we don't,

00:11:59.534 --> 00:12:02.806
then we're going to have boys
who leave elementary school saying,

00:12:02.830 --> 00:12:05.858
"Well I guess that was just
a place for girls, it wasn't for me.

00:12:05.882 --> 00:12:08.657
So I've got to do gaming,
or I've got to do sports."

00:12:09.114 --> 00:12:12.127
If we change these things,
if we pay attention to these things,

00:12:12.151 --> 00:12:14.070
and we reengage boys in their learning,

00:12:14.094 --> 00:12:17.268
they will leave the elementary
schools saying, "I'm smart."

00:12:18.092 --> 00:12:19.243
Thank you.

00:12:19.267 --> 00:12:21.743
(Applause)

title: Addicted to risk
transcript: I just did something I've never done before. I spent a week at sea on a research vessel. Now I'm not a scientist, but I was accompanying a remarkable scientific team from the University of South Florida who have been tracking the travels of BP's oil in the Gulf of Mexico. This is the boat we were on, by the way. The scientists I was with were not studying the effect of the oil and dispersants on the big stuff — the birds, the turtles, the dolphins, the glamorous stuff. They're looking at the really little stuff that gets eaten by the slightly less little stuff that eventually gets eaten by the big stuff. And what they're finding is that even trace amounts of oil and dispersants can be highly toxic to phytoplankton, which is very bad news, because so much life depends on it. So contrary to what we heard a few months back about how 75 percent of that oil sort of magically disappeared and we didn't have to worry about it, this disaster is still unfolding. It's still working its way up the food chain. Now this shouldn't come as a surprise to us. Rachel Carson — the godmother of modern environmentalism — warned us about this very thing back in 1962. She pointed out that the "control men" — as she called them — who carpet-bombed towns and fields with toxic insecticides like DDT, were only trying to kill the little stuff, the insects, not the birds. But they forgot this: the fact that birds dine on grubs, that robins eat lots of worms now saturated with DDT. And so, robin eggs failed to hatch, songbirds died en masse, towns fell silent. Thus the title "Silent Spring." I've been trying to pinpoint what keeps drawing me back to the Gulf of Mexico, because I'm Canadian, and I can draw no ancestral ties. And I think what it is is I don't think we have fully come to terms with the meaning of this disaster, with what it meant to witness a hole ripped in our world, with what it meant to watch the contents of the Earth gush forth on live TV, 24 hours a day, for months. After telling ourselves for so long that our tools and technology can control nature, suddenly we were face-to-face with our weakness, with our lack of control, as the oil burst out of every attempt to contain it — "top hats," "top kills" and, most memorably, the "junk shot" — the bright idea of firing old tires and golf balls down that hole in the world. But even more striking than the ferocious power emanating from that well was the recklessness with which that power was unleashed — the carelessness, the lack of planning that characterized the operation from drilling to clean-up. If there is one thing BP's watery improv act made clear, it is that, as a culture, we have become far too willing to gamble with things that are precious and irreplaceable, and to do so without a back-up plan, without an exit strategy. And BP was hardly our first experience of this in recent years. Our leaders barrel into wars, telling themselves happy stories about cakewalks and welcome parades. Then, it is years of deadly damage control, Frankensteins of sieges and surges and counter-insurgencies, and once again, no exit strategy. Our financial wizards routinely fall victim to similar overconfidence, convincing themselves that the latest bubble is a new kind of market — the kind that never goes down. And when it inevitably does, the best and the brightest reach for the financial equivalent of the junk shot — in this case, throwing massive amounts of much-needed public money down a very different kind of hole. As with BP, the hole does get plugged, at least temporarily, but not before exacting a tremendous price. We have to figure out why we keep letting this happen, because we are in the midst of what may be our highest-stakes gamble of all — deciding what to do, or not to do, about climate change. Now as you know, a great deal of time is spent, in this country and around the world, inside the climate debate, on the question of, "What if the IPC scientists are all wrong?" Now a far more relevant question — as MIT physicist Evelyn Fox Keller puts it — is, "What if those scientists are right?" Given the stakes, the climate crisis clearly calls for us to act based on the precautionary principle — the theory that holds that when human health and the environment are significantly at risk and when the potential damage is irreversible, we cannot afford to wait for perfect scientific certainty. Better to err on the side of caution. More overt, the burden of proving that a practice is safe should not be placed on the public that would be harmed, but rather on the industry that stands to profit. But climate policy in the wealthy world — to the extent that such a thing exists — is not based on precaution, but rather on cost-benefit analysis — finding the course of action that economists believe will have the least impact on our GDP. So rather than asking, as precaution would demand, what can we do as quickly as possible to avoid potential catastrophe, we ask bizarre questions like this: "What is the latest possible moment we can wait before we begin seriously lowering emissions? Can we put this off till 2020, 2030, 2050?" Or we ask, "How much hotter can we let the planet get and still survive? Can we go with two degrees, three degrees, or — where we're currently going — four degrees Celsius?" And by the way, the assumption that we can safely control the Earth's awesomely complex climate system as if it had a thermostat, making the planet not too hot, not too cold, but just right — sort of Goldilocks style — this is pure fantasy, and it's not coming from the climate scientists. It's coming from the economists imposing their mechanistic thinking on the science. The fact is that we simply don't know when the warming that we create will be utterly overwhelmed by feedback loops. So once again, why do we take these crazy risks with the precious? A range of explanations may be popping into your mind by now, like "greed." This is a popular explanation, and there's lots of truth to it, because taking big risks, as we all know, pays a lot of money. Another explanation that you often hear for recklessness is hubris. And greed and hubris are intimately intertwined when it comes to recklessness. For instance, if you happen to be a 35-year-old banker taking home 100 times more than a brain surgeon, then you need a narrative, you need a story that makes that disparity okay. And you actually don't have a lot of options. You're either an incredibly good scammer, and you're getting away with it — you gamed the system — or you're some kind of boy genius, the likes of which the world has never seen. Now both of these options — the boy genius and the scammer — are going to make you vastly overconfident and therefore more prone to taking even bigger risks in the future. By the way, Tony Hayward, the former CEO of BP, had a plaque on his desk inscribed with this inspirational slogan: "What would you attempt to do if you knew you could not fail?" Now this is actually a popular plaque, and this is a crowd of overachievers, so I'm betting that some of you have this plaque. Don't feel ashamed. Putting fear of failure out of your mind can be a very good thing if you're training for a triathlon or preparing to give a TEDTalk, but personally, I think people with the power to detonate our economy and ravage our ecology would do better having a picture of Icarus hanging from the wall, because — maybe not that one in particular — but I want them thinking about the possibility of failure all of the time. So we have greed, we've got overconfidence/hubris, but since we're here at TEDWomen, let's consider one other factor that could be contributing in some small way to societal recklessness. Now I'm not going to belabor this point, but studies do show that, as investors, women are much less prone to taking reckless risks than men, precisely because, as we've already heard, women tend not to suffer from overconfidence in the same way that men do. So it turns out that being paid less and praised less has its upsides — for society at least. The flipside of this is that constantly being told that you are gifted, chosen and born to rule has distinct societal downsides. And this problem — call it the "perils of privilege" — brings us closer, I think, to the root of our collective recklessness. Because none of us — at least in the global North — neither men nor women, are fully exempt from this message. Here's what I'm talking about. Whether we actively believe them or consciously reject them, our culture remains in the grips of certain archetypal stories about our supremacy over others and over nature — the narrative of the newly discovered frontier and the conquering pioneer, the narrative of manifest destiny, the narrative of apocalypse and salvation. And just when you think these stories are fading into history, and that we've gotten over them, they pop up in the strangest places. For instance, I stumbled across this advertisement outside the women's washroom in the Kansas City airport. It's for Motorola's new Rugged cell phone, and yes, it really does say, "Slap Mother Nature in the face." And I'm not just showing it to pick on Motorola — that's just a bonus. I'm showing it because — they're not a sponsor, are they? — because, in its own way, this is a crass version of our founding story. We slapped Mother Nature around and won, and we always win, because dominating nature is our destiny. But this is not the only fairytale we tell ourselves about nature. There's another one, equally important, about how that very same Mother Nature is so nurturing and so resilient that we can never make a dent in her abundance. Let's hear from Tony Hayward again. "The Gulf of Mexico is a very big ocean. The amount of oil and dispersants that we are putting into it is tiny in relation to the total water volume." In other words, the ocean is big; she can take it. It is this underlying assumption of limitlessness that makes it possible to take the reckless risks that we do. Because this is our real master-narrative: however much we mess up, there will always be more — more water, more land, more untapped resources. A new bubble will replace the old one. A new technology will come along to fix the messes we made with the last one. In a way, that is the story of the settling of the Americas, the supposedly inexhaustible frontier to which Europeans escaped. And it's also the story of modern capitalism, because it was the wealth from this land that gave birth to our economic system, one that cannot survive without perpetual growth and an unending supply of new frontiers. Now the problem is that the story was always a lie. The Earth always did have limits. They were just beyond our sights. And now we are hitting those limits on multiple fronts. I believe that we know this, yet we find ourselves trapped in a kind of narrative loop. Not only do we continue to tell and retell the same tired stories, but we are now doing so with a frenzy and a fury that, frankly, verges on camp. How else to explain the cultural space occupied by Sarah Palin? Now on the one hand, exhorting us to "drill, baby, drill," because God put those resources into the ground in order for us to exploit them, and on the other, glorying in the wilderness of Alaska's untouched beauty on her hit reality TV show. The twin message is as comforting as it is mad. Ignore those creeping fears that we have finally hit the wall. There are still no limits. There will always be another frontier. So stop worrying and keep shopping. Now, would that this were just about Sarah Palin and her reality TV show. In environmental circles, we often hear that, rather than shifting to renewables, we are continuing with business as usual. This assessment, unfortunately, is far too optimistic. The truth is that we have already exhausted so much of the easily accessible fossil fuels that we have already entered a far riskier business era, the era of extreme energy. So that means drilling for oil in the deepest water, including the icy Arctic seas, where a clean-up may simply be impossible. It means large-scale hydraulic fracking for gas and massive strip-mining operations for coal, the likes of which we haven't yet seen. And most controversially, it means the tar sands. I'm always surprised by how little people outside of Canada know about the Alberta Tar Sands, which this year are projected to become the number one source of imported oil to the United States. It's worth taking a moment to understand this practice, because I believe it speaks to recklessness and the path we're on like little else. So this is where the tar sands live, under one of the last magnificent Boreal forests. The oil is not liquid. You can't just drill a hole and pump it out. Tar sand's oil is solid, mixed in with the soil. So to get at it, you first have to get rid of the trees. Then, you rip off the topsoil and get at that oily sand. The process requires a huge amount of water, which is then pumped into massive toxic tailing ponds. That's very bad news for local indigenous people living downstream who are reporting alarmingly high cancer rates. Now looking at these images, it's difficult to grasp the scale of this operation, which can already be seen from space and could grow to an area the size of England. I find it helps actually to look at the dump trucks that move the earth, the largest ever built. That's a person down there by the wheel. My point is that this is not oil drilling. It's not even mining. It is terrestrial skinning. Vast, vivid landscapes are being gutted, left monochromatic gray. Now I should confess that as [far as] I'm concerned this would be an abomination if it emitted not one particle of carbon. But the truth is that, on average, turning that gunk into crude oil produces about three times more greenhouse gas pollution than it does to produce conventional oil in Canada. How else to describe this, but as a form of mass insanity? Just when we know we need to be learning to live on the surface of our planet, off the power of sun, wind and waves, we are frantically digging to get at the dirtiest, highest-emitting stuff imaginable. This is where our story of endless growth has taken us, to this black hole at the center of my country — a place of such planetary pain that, like the BP gusher, one can only stand to look at it for so long. As Jared Diamond and others have shown us, this is how civilizations commit suicide, by slamming their foot on the accelerator at the exact moment when they should be putting on the brakes. The problem is that our master-narrative has an answer for that too. At the very last minute, we are going to get saved just like in every Hollywood movie, just like in the Rapture. But, of course, our secular religion is technology. Now, you may have noticed more and more headlines like these. The idea behind this form of "geoengineering" as it's called, is that, as the planet heats up, we may be able to shoot sulfates and aluminum particles into the stratosphere to reflect some of the sun's rays back to space, thereby cooling the planet. The wackiest plan — and I'm not making this up — would put what is essentially a garden hose 18-and-a-half miles high into the sky, suspended by balloons, to spew sulfur dioxide. So, solving the problem of pollution with more pollution. Think of it as the ultimate junk shot. The serious scientists involved in this research all stress that these techniques are entirely untested. They don't know if they'll work, and they have no idea what kind of terrifying side effects they could unleash. Nevertheless, the mere mention of geoengineering is being greeted in some circles, particularly media circles, with a relief tinged with euphoria. An escape hatch has been reached. A new frontier has been found. Most importantly, we don't have to change our lifestyles after all. You see, for some people, their savior is a guy in a flowing robe. For other people, it's a guy with a garden hose. We badly need some new stories. We need stories that have different kinds of heroes willing to take different kinds of risks — risks that confront recklessness head on, that put the precautionary principle into practice, even if that means through direct action — like hundreds of young people willing to get arrested, blocking dirty power plants or fighting mountaintop-removal coal mining. We need stories that replace that linear narrative of endless growth with circular narratives that remind us that what goes around comes around. That this is our only home. There is no escape hatch. Call it karma, call it physics, action and reaction, call it precaution — the principle that reminds us that life is too precious to be risked for any profit. Thank you. (Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I just did something I've never done before.

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
I spent a week at sea on a research vessel.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:19.958
Now I'm not a scientist,

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
but I was accompanying a remarkable scientific team

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
from the University of South Florida

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
who have been tracking the travels of BP's oil

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958
in the Gulf of Mexico.

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
This is the boat we were on, by the way.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
The scientists I was with

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
were not studying the effect of the oil and dispersants on the big stuff --

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
the birds, the turtles,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
the dolphins, the glamorous stuff.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
They're looking at the really little stuff

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
that gets eaten by the slightly less little stuff

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
that eventually gets eaten by the big stuff.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
And what they're finding

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
is that even trace amounts of oil and dispersants

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
can be highly toxic to phytoplankton,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
which is very bad news,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
because so much life depends on it.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
So contrary to what we heard a few months back

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
about how 75 percent of that oil

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
sort of magically disappeared

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
and we didn't have to worry about it,

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:13.958
this disaster is still unfolding.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:16.958
It's still working its way up the food chain.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.958
Now this shouldn't come as a surprise to us.

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:21.958
Rachel Carson --

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:23.958
the godmother of modern environmentalism --

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:25.958
warned us about this very thing

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
back in 1962.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
She pointed out that the "control men" --

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
as she called them --

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
who carpet-bombed towns and fields

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:36.958
with toxic insecticides like DDT,

00:01:36.958 --> 00:01:39.958
were only trying to kill the little stuff, the insects,

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
not the birds.

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
But they forgot this:

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
the fact that birds dine on grubs,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
that robins eat lots of worms

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
now saturated with DDT.

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
And so, robin eggs failed to hatch,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.958
songbirds died en masse,

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.958
towns fell silent.

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
Thus the title "Silent Spring."

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
I've been trying to pinpoint

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
what keeps drawing me back to the Gulf of Mexico,

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
because I'm Canadian,

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
and I can draw no ancestral ties.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
And I think what it is

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
is I don't think we have fully come to terms

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
with the meaning of this disaster,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
with what it meant to witness a hole

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
ripped in our world,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
with what it meant to watch the contents of the Earth

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
gush forth on live TV,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
24 hours a day,

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
for months.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
After telling ourselves for so long

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
that our tools and technology can control nature,

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
suddenly we were face-to-face

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
with our weakness,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
with our lack of control,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
as the oil burst out

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
of every attempt to contain it --

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
"top hats," "top kills"

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
and, most memorably, the "junk shot" --

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
the bright idea

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.958
of firing old tires and golf balls

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
down that hole in the world.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
But even more striking

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:04.958
than the ferocious power emanating from that well

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
was the recklessness

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
with which that power was unleashed --

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
the carelessness, the lack of planning

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
that characterized the operation

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
from drilling to clean-up.

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
If there is one thing

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
BP's watery improv act made clear,

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
it is that, as a culture,

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
we have become far too willing to gamble

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
with things that are precious

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
and irreplaceable,

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:32.958
and to do so without a back-up plan,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
without an exit strategy.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
And BP was hardly

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
our first experience of this in recent years.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
Our leaders barrel into wars,

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
telling themselves happy stories

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
about cakewalks and welcome parades.

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
Then, it is years of deadly damage control,

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
Frankensteins of sieges and surges

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
and counter-insurgencies,

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:56.958
and once again, no exit strategy.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
Our financial wizards routinely fall victim

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
to similar overconfidence,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
convincing themselves that the latest bubble

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
is a new kind of market --

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
the kind that never goes down.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
And when it inevitably does,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
the best and the brightest

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
reach for the financial equivalent of the junk shot --

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
in this case, throwing massive amounts

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
of much-needed public money

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
down a very different kind of hole.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
As with BP, the hole does get plugged,

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
at least temporarily,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
but not before

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
exacting a tremendous price.

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:30.958
We have to figure out

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
why we keep letting this happen,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
because we are in the midst

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
of what may be our highest-stakes gamble of all --

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
deciding what to do, or not to do,

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
about climate change.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
Now as you know,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
a great deal of time is spent,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
in this country and around the world,

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
inside the climate debate,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
on the question of, "What if the IPC scientists

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:54.958
are all wrong?"

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Now a far more relevant question --

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:59.958
as MIT physicist Evelyn Fox Keller puts it --

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:03.958
is, "What if those scientists are right?"

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
Given the stakes, the climate crisis

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:08.958
clearly calls for us to act

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
based on the precautionary principle --

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
the theory that holds

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
that when human health and the environment

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
are significantly at risk

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
and when the potential damage is irreversible,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:22.958
we cannot afford to wait

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:24.958
for perfect scientific certainty.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
Better to err on the side of caution.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
More overt, the burden of proving

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
that a practice is safe

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
should not be placed on the public that would be harmed,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
but rather on the industry that stands to profit.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
But climate policy in the wealthy world --

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:43.958
to the extent that such a thing exists --

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
is not based on precaution,

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:48.958
but rather on cost-benefit analysis --

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
finding the course of action that economists believe

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
will have the least impact

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
on our GDP.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
So rather than asking, as precaution would demand,

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
what can we do as quickly as possible

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:02.958
to avoid potential catastrophe,

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:05.958
we ask bizarre questions like this:

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
"What is the latest possible moment we can wait

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:11.958
before we begin seriously lowering emissions?

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
Can we put this off till 2020,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
2030, 2050?"

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
Or we ask,

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
"How much hotter can we let the planet get

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
and still survive?

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
Can we go with two degrees, three degrees, or --

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
where we're currently going --

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
four degrees Celsius?"

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
And by the way,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
the assumption that we can safely control

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
the Earth's awesomely complex climate system

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
as if it had a thermostat,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
making the planet not too hot, not too cold,

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
but just right -- sort of Goldilocks style --

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
this is pure fantasy,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
and it's not coming from the climate scientists.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
It's coming from the economists

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
imposing their mechanistic thinking

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
on the science.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
The fact is that we simply don't know

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
when the warming that we create

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
will be utterly overwhelmed

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
by feedback loops.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
So once again,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
why do we take these crazy risks

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
with the precious?

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
A range of explanations

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
may be popping into your mind by now,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
like "greed."

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
This is a popular explanation, and there's lots of truth to it,

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
because taking big risks, as we all know,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
pays a lot of money.

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:24.958
Another explanation that you often hear for recklessness

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
is hubris.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
And greed and hubris

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
are intimately intertwined

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
when it comes to recklessness.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
For instance, if you happen to be a 35-year-old banker

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
taking home 100 times more

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
than a brain surgeon,

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
then you need a narrative,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
you need a story

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
that makes that disparity okay.

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
And you actually don't have a lot of options.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
You're either an incredibly good scammer,

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
and you're getting away with it -- you gamed the system --

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
or you're some kind of boy genius,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:58.958
the likes of which the world has never seen.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
Now both of these options -- the boy genius and the scammer --

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
are going to make you vastly overconfident

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and therefore more prone

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
to taking even bigger risks in the future.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
By the way, Tony Hayward, the former CEO of BP,

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
had a plaque on his desk

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
inscribed with this inspirational slogan:

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
"What would you attempt to do

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
if you knew you could not fail?"

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Now this is actually a popular plaque,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
and this is a crowd of overachievers,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
so I'm betting that some of you have this plaque.

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
Don't feel ashamed.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
Putting fear of failure out of your mind

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
can be a very good thing

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
if you're training for a triathlon

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
or preparing to give a TEDTalk,

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
but personally, I think people with the power

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
to detonate our economy and ravage our ecology

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
would do better having

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
a picture of Icarus hanging from the wall,

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
because -- maybe not that one in particular --

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
but I want them thinking about the possibility of failure

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
all of the time.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
So we have greed,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
we've got overconfidence/hubris,

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
but since we're here at TEDWomen,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
let's consider one other factor

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
that could be contributing in some small way

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
to societal recklessness.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
Now I'm not going to belabor this point,

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
but studies do show that, as investors,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
women are much less prone

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
to taking reckless risks than men,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
precisely because, as we've already heard,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:25.958
women tend not to suffer from overconfidence

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
in the same way that men do.

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
So it turns out

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
that being paid less and praised less

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
has its upsides --

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
for society at least.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
The flipside of this

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
is that constantly being told

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
that you are gifted, chosen

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
and born to rule

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
has distinct societal downsides.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
And this problem -- call it the "perils of privilege" --

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
brings us closer, I think,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
to the root of our collective recklessness.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
Because none of us -- at least in the global North --

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
neither men nor women,

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:01.958
are fully exempt from this message.

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
Here's what I'm talking about.

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
Whether we actively believe them

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
or consciously reject them,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
our culture remains in the grips

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
of certain archetypal stories

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
about our supremacy

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
over others and over nature --

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.958
the narrative of the newly discovered frontier

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and the conquering pioneer,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
the narrative of manifest destiny,

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
the narrative of apocalypse and salvation.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
And just when you think these stories are fading into history,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
and that we've gotten over them,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
they pop up in the strangest places.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
For instance, I stumbled across this advertisement

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
outside the women's washroom

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
in the Kansas City airport.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
It's for Motorola's new Rugged cell phone,

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
and yes, it really does say,

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
"Slap Mother Nature in the face."

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
And I'm not just showing it to pick on Motorola --

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
that's just a bonus.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
I'm showing it because --

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
they're not a sponsor, are they? --

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
because, in its own way,

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
this is a crass version

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
of our founding story.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
We slapped Mother Nature around and won,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
and we always win,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
because dominating nature is our destiny.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
But this is not the only fairytale we tell ourselves about nature.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
There's another one, equally important,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
about how that very same Mother Nature

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
is so nurturing and so resilient

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
that we can never make a dent in her abundance.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
Let's hear from Tony Hayward again.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
"The Gulf of Mexico is a very big ocean.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
The amount of oil and dispersants that we are putting into it

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
is tiny in relation to the total water volume."

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
In other words, the ocean is big;

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
she can take it.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
It is this underlying assumption of limitlessness

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
that makes it possible

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
to take the reckless risks that we do.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Because this is our real master-narrative:

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
however much we mess up,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
there will always be more --

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:52.958
more water, more land,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
more untapped resources.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
A new bubble will replace the old one.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
A new technology will come along

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
to fix the messes we made with the last one.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
In a way, that is the story

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
of the settling of the Americas,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
the supposedly inexhaustible frontier

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
to which Europeans escaped.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
And it's also the story of modern capitalism,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
because it was the wealth from this land

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
that gave birth to our economic system,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
one that cannot survive without perpetual growth

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and an unending supply

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
of new frontiers.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
Now the problem is

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
that the story was always a lie.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
The Earth always did have limits.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
They were just beyond our sights.

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
And now we are hitting those limits

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
on multiple fronts.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
I believe that we know this,

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:43.958
yet we find ourselves trapped in a kind of narrative loop.

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Not only do we continue to tell and retell

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
the same tired stories,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
but we are now doing so

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
with a frenzy and a fury

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.958
that, frankly, verges on camp.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
How else to explain the cultural space

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
occupied by Sarah Palin?

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:02.958
Now on the one hand,

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
exhorting us to "drill, baby, drill,"

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:07.958
because God put those resources into the ground

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
in order for us to exploit them,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
and on the other, glorying in the wilderness

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
of Alaska's untouched beauty

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:18.958
on her hit reality TV show.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:21.958
The twin message is as comforting as it is mad.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
Ignore those creeping fears

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
that we have finally hit the wall.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
There are still no limits.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
There will always be another frontier.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
So stop worrying and keep shopping.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
Now, would that this were just about

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
Sarah Palin and her reality TV show.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
In environmental circles,

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:42.958
we often hear that, rather than shifting to renewables,

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:45.958
we are continuing with business as usual.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
This assessment, unfortunately,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
is far too optimistic.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:52.958
The truth is that we have already exhausted

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
so much of the easily accessible fossil fuels

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
that we have already entered

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
a far riskier business era,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:02.958
the era of extreme energy.

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
So that means drilling for oil in the deepest water,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
including the icy Arctic seas,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
where a clean-up may simply be impossible.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
It means large-scale hydraulic fracking for gas

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
and massive strip-mining operations for coal,

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
the likes of which we haven't yet seen.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
And most controversially, it means the tar sands.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
I'm always surprised by how little

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
people outside of Canada

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
know about the Alberta Tar Sands,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
which this year are projected to become

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
the number one source of imported oil

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
to the United States.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
It's worth taking a moment to understand this practice,

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
because I believe it speaks to recklessness

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and the path we're on

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
like little else.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
So this is where the tar sands live,

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
under one of the last magnificent

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
Boreal forests.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
The oil is not liquid.

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
You can't just drill a hole and pump it out.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Tar sand's oil is solid,

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
mixed in with the soil.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
So to get at it,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
you first have to get rid of the trees.

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
Then, you rip off the topsoil

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
and get at that oily sand.

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
The process requires a huge amount of water,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:15.958
which is then pumped into massive toxic tailing ponds.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
That's very bad news for local indigenous people

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
living downstream

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
who are reporting alarmingly high cancer rates.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
Now looking at these images,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
it's difficult to grasp the scale of this operation,

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
which can already be seen from space

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
and could grow to an area the size of England.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
I find it helps actually

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:38.958
to look at the dump trucks that move the earth,

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:40.958
the largest ever built.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
That's a person down there by the wheel.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
My point is that

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
this is not oil drilling.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
It's not even mining.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
It is terrestrial skinning.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
Vast, vivid landscapes

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
are being gutted,

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
left monochromatic gray.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
Now I should confess that as [far as] I'm concerned

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
this would be an abomination

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
if it emitted not one particle of carbon.

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
But the truth is that, on average,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
turning that gunk into crude oil

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
produces about three times more greenhouse gas pollution

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
than it does to produce conventional oil

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
in Canada.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
How else to describe this,

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:21.958
but as a form of mass insanity?

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:24.958
Just when we know we need to be learning

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:26.958
to live on the surface of our planet,

00:16:26.958 --> 00:16:29.958
off the power of sun, wind and waves,

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
we are frantically digging

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
to get at the dirtiest,

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
highest-emitting stuff imaginable.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:38.958
This is where our story of endless growth

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
has taken us,

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
to this black hole at the center of my country --

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
a place of such planetary pain

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
that, like the BP gusher,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:51.958
one can only stand to look at it for so long.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:54.958
As Jared Diamond and others have shown us,

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
this is how civilizations commit suicide,

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
by slamming their foot on the accelerator

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
at the exact moment

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:04.958
when they should be putting on the brakes.

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:07.958
The problem is that our master-narrative

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
has an answer for that too.

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
At the very last minute, we are going to get saved

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
just like in every Hollywood movie,

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
just like in the Rapture.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
But, of course, our secular religion is technology.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
Now, you may have noticed

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:25.958
more and more headlines like these.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:28.958
The idea behind this form of "geoengineering" as it's called,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
is that, as the planet heats up,

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:33.958
we may be able to shoot sulfates and aluminum particles

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
into the stratosphere

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:37.958
to reflect some of the sun's rays

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:39.958
back to space,

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
thereby cooling the planet.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:44.958
The wackiest plan -- and I'm not making this up --

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
would put what is essentially a garden hose

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
18-and-a-half miles high into the sky,

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
suspended by balloons,

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:54.958
to spew sulfur dioxide.

00:17:54.958 --> 00:17:57.958
So, solving the problem of pollution with more pollution.

00:17:57.958 --> 00:18:00.958
Think of it as the ultimate junk shot.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.958
The serious scientists involved in this research

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
all stress that these techniques

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:07.958
are entirely untested.

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:09.958
They don't know if they'll work,

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:11.958
and they have no idea

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:14.958
what kind of terrifying side effects they could unleash.

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:17.958
Nevertheless, the mere mention of geoengineering

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
is being greeted in some circles,

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:21.958
particularly media circles,

00:18:21.958 --> 00:18:23.958
with a relief tinged with euphoria.

00:18:23.958 --> 00:18:25.958
An escape hatch has been reached.

00:18:25.958 --> 00:18:27.958
A new frontier has been found.

00:18:27.958 --> 00:18:29.958
Most importantly,

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.958
we don't have to change our lifestyles after all.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
You see, for some people,

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:35.958
their savior is a guy in a flowing robe.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:38.958
For other people, it's a guy with a garden hose.

00:18:39.958 --> 00:18:42.958
We badly need some new stories.

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:45.958
We need stories that have different kinds of heroes

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:48.958
willing to take different kinds of risks --

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:50.958
risks that confront recklessness head on,

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
that put the precautionary principle into practice,

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
even if that means through direct action --

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:58.958
like hundreds of young people willing to get arrested,

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:00.958
blocking dirty power plants

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:03.958
or fighting mountaintop-removal coal mining.

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:05.958
We need stories

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:08.958
that replace that linear narrative of endless growth

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:10.958
with circular narratives

00:19:10.958 --> 00:19:12.958
that remind us

00:19:12.958 --> 00:19:14.958
that what goes around comes around.

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:16.958
That this is our only home.

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:18.958
There is no escape hatch.

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
Call it karma, call it physics,

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
action and reaction, call it precaution --

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:26.958
the principle that reminds us

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:28.958
that life is too precious to be risked

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
for any profit.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:32.958
Thank you.

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:39.958
(Applause)

title: Singing after a double lung transplant
transcript: You may not know this, but you are celebrating an anniversary with me. I'm not married, but one year ago today, I woke up from a month-long coma, following a double lung transplant. Crazy, I know. Insane. Thank you.Six years before that, I was starting my career as an opera singer in Europe, when I was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary hypertension — also known as PH. It happens when there's a thickening in the pulmonary veins, making the right side of the heart work overtime, and causing what I call the reverse-Grinch effect. My heart was three-and-a-half sizes too big. Physical activity becomes very difficult for people with this condition, and usually after two to five years, you die. I went to see this specialist, and she was top-of-the-field and told me I had to stop singing. She said, "Those high notes are going to kill you." While she didn't have any medical evidence to back up her claim that there was a relationship between operatic arias and pulmonary hypertension, she was absolutely emphatic I was singing my own obituary. I was very limited by my condition, physically. But I was not limited when I sang, and as air came up from my lungs, through my vocal cords and passed my lips as sound, it was the closest thing I had ever come to transcendence. And just because of someone's hunch, I wasn't going to give it up.Thankfully, I met Reda Girgis, who is dry as toast, but he and his team at Johns Hopkins didn't just want me to survive, they wanted me to live a meaningful life. This meant making trade-offs. I come from Colorado. It's a mile high, and I grew up there with my 10 brothers and sisters and two adoring parents. Well, the altitude exacerbated my symptoms. So I moved to Baltimore to be near my doctors and enrolled in a conservatory nearby. I couldn't walk as much as I used to, so I opted for five-inch heels. And I gave up salt, I went vegan, and I started taking huge doses of sildenafil, also known as Viagra.(Laughter)My father and my grandfather were always looking for the newest thing in alternative or traditional therapies for PH, but after six months, I couldn't walk up a small hill. I couldn't climb a flight of stairs. I could barely stand up without feeling like I was going to faint. I had a heart catheterization, where they measure this internal arterial pulmonary pressure, which is supposed to be between 15 and 20. Mine was 146. I like to do things big, and it meant one thing: there is a big gun treatment for pulmonary hypertension called Flolan, and it's not just a drug; it's a way of life. Doctors insert a catheter into your chest, which is attached to a pump that weighs about four-and-a-half pounds. Every day, 24 hours, that pump is at your side, administering medicine directly to your heart, and it's not a particularly preferable medicine in many senses. This is a list of the side effects: if you eat too much salt, like a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, you'll probably end up in the ICU. If you go through a metal detector, you'll probably die. If you get a bubble in your medicine — because you have to mix it every morning — and it stays in there, you probably die. If you run out of medicine, you definitely die.No one wants to go on Flolan. But when I needed it, it was a godsend. Within a few days, I could walk again. Within a few weeks, I was performing, and in a few months, I debuted at the Kennedy Center. The pump was a little bit problematic when performing, so I'd attach it to my inner thigh with the help of the girdle and an ACE bandage. Literally hundreds of elevator rides were spent with me alone stuffing the pump into my Spanx, hoping the doors wouldn't open unexpectedly. And the tubing coming out of my chest was a nightmare for costume designers. I graduated from graduate school in 2006, and I got a fellowship to go back to Europe. A few days after arriving, I met this wonderful, old conductor who started casting me in all of these roles. And before long, I was commuting between Budapest, Milan and Florence. Though I was attached to this ugly, unwanted, high-maintenance, mechanical pet, my life was kind of like the happy part in an opera — very complicated, but in a good way.Then in February of 2008, my grandfather passed away. He was a big figure in all of our lives, and we loved him very much. It certainly didn't prepare me for what came next. Seven weeks later, I got a call from my family. My father had been in a catastrophic car accident, and he died. At 24, my death would have been entirely expected. But his — well, the only way I can articulate how it felt was that it precipitated my medical decline. Against my doctors' and family's wishes, I needed to go back for the funeral. I had to say goodbye in some way, shape or form. But soon I was showing signs of right-heart failure, and I had to return to sea level, doing so knowing that I probably would never see my home again.I canceled most of my engagements that summer, but I had one left in Tel Aviv, so I went. After one performance, I could barely drag myself from the stage to the taxicab. I sat down and felt the blood rush down from my face, and in the heat of the desert, I was freezing cold. My fingers started turning blue, and I was like, "What is going on here?" I heard my heart's valves snapping open and closed. The cab stopped, and I pulled my body from it feeling each ounce of weight as I walked to the elevator. I fell through my apartment door and crawled to the bathroom where I found my problem: I had forgotten to mix in the most important part of my medicine. I was dying, and if I didn't mix that stuff up fast, I would never leave that apartment alive. I started mixing, and I felt like everything was going to fall out through one hole or another, but I just kept on going. Finally, with the last bottle in and the last bubble out, I attached the pump to the tubing and lay there hoping it would kick in soon enough. If it didn't, I'd probably see my father sooner than I anticipated. Thankfully, in a few minutes, I saw the signature hive-like rash appear on my legs, which is a side effect of the medication, and I knew I'd be okay.We're not big on fear in my family, but I was scared. I went back to the States, anticipating I'd return to Europe, but the heart catheterization showed that I wasn't going anywhere further that a flight-for-life from Johns Hopkins Hospital. I performed here and there, but as my condition deteriorated, so did my voice. My doctor wanted me to get on the list for a lung transplant. I didn't. I had two friends who had recently died months after having very challenging surgeries. I knew another young man, though, who had PH who died while waiting for one. I wanted to live. I thought stem cells were a good option, but they hadn't developed to a point where I could take advantage of them yet. I officially took a break from singing, and I went to the Cleveland Clinic to be reevaluated for the third time in five years, for transplant. I was sitting there kind of unenthusiastically talking with the head transplant surgeon, and I asked him if I needed a transplant, what I could do to prepare. He said, "Be happy. A happy patient is a healthy patient." It was like in one verbal swoop he had channeled my thoughts on life and medicine and Confucius. I still didn't want a transplant, but in a month, I was back in the hospital with some severely edemic kankles — very attractive. And it was right-heart failure.I finally decided it was time to take my doctor's advice. It was time for me to go to Cleveland and to start the agonizing wait for a match. But the next morning, while I was still in the hospital, I got a telephone call. It was my doctor in Cleveland, Marie Budev. And they had lungs. It was a match. They were from Texas. And everybody was really happy for me, but me. Because, despite their problems, I had spent my whole life training my lungs, and I was not particularly enthusiastic about giving them up. I flew to Cleveland, and my family rushed there in hopes that they would meet me and say what we knew might be our final goodbye. But organs don't wait, and I went into surgery before I could say goodbye. The last thing I remember was lying on a white blanket, telling my surgeon that I needed to see my mother again, and to please try and save my voice. I fell into this apocalyptic dream world.During the thirteen-and-a-half-hour surgery, I flatlined twice, 40 quarts of blood were infused into my body. And in my surgeon's 20-year career, he said it was among the most difficult transplants that he's ever performed. They left my chest open for two weeks. You could see my over-sized heart beating inside of it. I was on a dozen machines that were keeping me alive. An infection ravaged my skin. I had hoped my voice would be saved, but my doctors knew that the breathing tubes going down my throat might have already destroyed it. If they stayed in, there was no way I would ever sing again. So my doctor got the ENT, the top guy at the clinic, to come down and give me surgery to move the tubes around my voice box. He said it would kill me. So my own surgeon performed the procedure in a last-ditch attempt to save my voice.Though my mom couldn't say goodbye to me before the surgery, she didn't leave my side in the months of recovery that followed. And if you want an example of perseverance, grit and strength in a beautiful, little package, it is her. One year ago to this very day, I woke up. I was 95 lbs. There were a dozen tubes coming in and out of my body. I couldn't walk, I couldn't talk, I couldn't eat, I couldn't move, I certainly couldn't sing, I couldn't even breathe, but when I looked up and I saw my mother, I couldn't help but smile.Whether by a Mack truck or by heart failure or faulty lungs, death happens. But life isn't really just about avoiding death, is it? It's about living. Medical conditions don't negate the human condition. And when people are allowed to pursue their passions, doctors will find they have better, happier and healthier patients. My parents were totally stressed out about me going and auditioning and traveling and performing all over the place, but they knew that it was much better for me to do that than be preoccupied with my own mortality all of the time. And I'm so grateful they did.This past summer, when I was running and singing and dancing and playing with my nieces and my nephews and my brothers and my sisters and my mother and my grandmother in the Colorado Rockies, I couldn't help but think of that doctor who told me that I couldn't sing. And I wanted to tell her, and I want to tell you, we need to stop letting disease divorce us from our dreams. When we do, we will find that patients don't just survive; we thrive. And some of us might even sing.(Applause) [Singing: French]Thank you. (Applause) Thank you. And I'd like to thank my pianist, Monica Lee. (Applause) Thank you so much. Thank you.

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
You may not know this,

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.958

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
but one year ago today,

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
I woke up

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:27.958
from a month-long coma,

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:30.958
following a double lung transplant.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
Crazy, I know. Insane.

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
Thank you.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.958
Six years before that,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.958
I was starting my career

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
as an opera singer in Europe,

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:47.958
when I was diagnosed with

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:50.958
idiopathic pulmonary hypertension --

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
also known as PH.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:55.958
It happens when there's a thickening

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
in the pulmonary veins,

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
making the right side of the heart

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
work overtime,

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:03.958
