00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
I'm speaking to you about what I call the "mesh."

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.958
It's essentially a fundamental shift

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:19.958
in our relationship with stuff, with the things in our lives.

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
And it's starting to look at --

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
not always and not for everything --

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
but in certain moments of time,

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
access to certain kinds of goods and service

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
will trump ownership of them.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
And so it's the pursuit of better things,

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
easily shared.

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:37.958
And we come from a long tradition of sharing.

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.958
We've shared transportation.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:42.958
We've shared wine and food

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:45.958
and other sorts of fabulous experiences

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
in coffee bars in Amsterdam.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:51.958
We've also shared other sorts of entertainment --

00:00:51.958 --> 00:00:53.958
sports arenas, public parks,

00:00:53.958 --> 00:00:55.958
concert halls, libraries,

00:00:55.958 --> 00:00:57.958
universities.

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
All these things are share-platforms,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
but sharing ultimately starts and ends

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
with what I refer to

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:06.958
as the "mother of all share-platforms."

00:01:06.958 --> 00:01:08.958
And as I think about the mesh

00:01:08.958 --> 00:01:10.958
and I think about, well, what's driving it,

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
how come it's happening now,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
I think there's a number of vectors

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
that I want to give you as background.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
One is the recession --

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
that the recession has caused us

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
to rethink our relationship

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
with the things in our lives relative to the value --

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
so starting to align the value

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
with the true cost.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:31.958
Secondly, population growth

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
and density into cities.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
More people, smaller spaces,

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
less stuff.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
Climate change:

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
we're trying to reduce the stress

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
in our personal lives and in our communities

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
and on the planet.

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
Also, there's been this recent distrust

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
of big brands, global big brands,

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
in a bunch of different industries,

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
and that's created an opening.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
Research is showing here, in the States,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
and in Canada and Western Europe,

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
that most of us are much more open

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
to local companies,

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:05.958
or brands that maybe we haven't heard of.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:07.958
Whereas before, we went with the big brands

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
that we were sure we trusted.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
And last is that

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
we're more connected now to more people on the planet

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
than ever before --

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
except for if you're sitting next to someone.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
(Laughter)

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
The other thing that's worth considering

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
is that we've made a huge investment

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
over decades and decades,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
and tens of billions of dollars

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
have gone into this investment

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
that now is our inheritance.

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
It's a physical infrastructure

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
that allows us to get from point A to point B

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
and move things that way.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
It's also -- Web and mobile

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
allow us to be connected

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:46.958
and create all kinds of platforms and systems,

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
and the investment of those technologies

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
and that infrastructure

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
is really our inheritance.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
It allows us to engage

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
in really new and interesting ways.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
And so for me, a mesh company, the "classic" mesh company,

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
brings together these three things:

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
our ability to connect to each other --

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
most of us are walking around with these mobile devices

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
that are GPS-enabled and Web-enabled --

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
allows us to find each other

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:12.958
and find things in time and space.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
And third is that physical things

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
are readable on a map --

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
so restaurants, a variety of venues,

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
but also with GPS and other technology

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
like RFID

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
and it continues to expand beyond that,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
we can also track things that are moving,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
like a car, a taxicab, a transit system,

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
a box that's moving through time and space.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
And so that sets up

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
for making access to get goods and services

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
more convenient and less costly in many cases

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
than owning them.

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:43.958
For example, I want to use Zipcar.

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:45.958
How many people here have experienced

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:48.958
car-sharing or bike-sharing?

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:50.958
Wow, that's great. Okay, thank you.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
Basically Zipcar

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
is the largest car-sharing company in the world.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
They did not invent car-sharing.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
Car-sharing was actually invented in Europe.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
One of the founders went to Switzerland,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
saw it implemented someplace,

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
said, "Wow, that looks really cool.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
I think we can do that in Cambridge,"

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
brought it to Cambridge

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
and they started -- two women --

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
Robin Chase being the other person who started it.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
Zipcar got some really important things right.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
First, they really understood

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
that a brand is a voice and a product is a souvenir.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And so they were very clever

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
about the way that they packaged car-sharing.

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
They made it sexy. They made it fresh.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
They made it aspirational.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
If you were a member of the club,

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
when you're a member of a club, you're a Zipster.

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
The cars they picked didn't look like ex-cop cars

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
that were hollowed out or something.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
They picked these sexy cars.

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
They targeted to universities.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
They made sure that the demographic

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
for who they were targeting and the car was all matching.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
It was a very nice experience,

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
and the cars were clean and reliable, and it all worked.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
And so from a branding perspective, they got a lot right.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
But they understood fundamentally

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
that they are not a car company.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
They understand that they are an information company.

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:04.958
Because when we buy a car

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
we go to the dealer once, we have an interaction, and we're chow --

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:09.958
usually as quickly as possible.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
But when you're sharing a car and you have a car-share service,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
you might use an E.V. to commute,

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
you get a truck because you're doing a home project.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
When you pick your aunt up at the airport, you get a sedan.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
And you're going to the mountains to ski,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
you get different accessories put on the car

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
for doing that sort of thing.

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
Meanwhile, these guys are sitting back,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
collecting all sorts of data

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:35.958
about our behavior and how we interact with the service.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
And so it's not only an option for them,

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
but I believe it's an imperative

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
for Zipcar and other mesh companies

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
to actually just wow us,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
to be like a concierge service.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
Because we give them so much information,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
and they are entitled to really see

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
how it is that we're moving.

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
They're in really good shape to anticipate

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
what we're going to want next.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
And so what percent of the day

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
do you think the average person uses a car?

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
What percentage of the time?

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
Any guesses?

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:14.958
Those are really very good.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
I was imagining it was like

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
20 percent when I first started.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
The number across the U.S. and Western Europe

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
is eight percent.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:26.958
And so basically even if you think it's 10 percent,

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
90 percent of the time,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
something that costs us a lot of money --

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
personally, and also we organize our cities around it

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
and all sorts of things --

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
90 percent of the time it's sitting around.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
So for this reason,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
I think one of the other themes with the mesh

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
is essentially that, if we squeeze hard

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
on things that we've thrown away,

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
there's a lot of value in those things.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
What set up with Zipcar -- Zipcar started in 2000.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
In the last year, 2010,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
two car companies started,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
one that's in the U.K. called WhipCar,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
and the other one, RelayRides, in the U.S.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
They're both peer-to-peer car-sharing services,

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
because the two things that really work for car-sharing

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
is, one, the car has to be available,

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
and two, it's within one or two blocks

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
of where you stand.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
Well the car that's one or two blocks from your home or your office

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
is probably your neighbor's car,

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
and it's probably also available.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
So people have created this business.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
Zipcar started a decade earlier,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
in 2000.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
It took them six years

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
to get 1,000 cars in service.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
WhipCar, which started April of last year,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
it took them six months

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:35.958
to get 1,000 cars in the service.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
So, really interesting.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
People are making anywhere between

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
200 and 700 dollars a month

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
letting their neighbors use their car when they're not using it.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
So it's like vacation rentals for cars.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
Since I'm here --

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
and I hope some people in the audience

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
are in the car business --

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
(Laughter)

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
-- I'm thinking that, coming from the technology side of things --

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
we saw cable-ready TVs

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and WiFi-ready Notebooks --

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.958
it would be really great if, any minute now,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
you guys could start rolling share-ready cars off.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
Because it just creates more flexibility.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
It allows us as owners to have other options.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
And I think we're going there anyway.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
The opportunity and the challenge with mesh businesses --

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
and those are businesses like Zipcar or Netflix

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
that are full mesh businesses,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
or other ones where you have a lot of the car companies,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
car manufacturers,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
who are beginning to offer

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
their own car-share services

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
as well as a second flanker brand,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
or as really a test, I think --

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
is to make sharing irresistible.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
We have experiences in our lives, certainly,

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
when sharing has been irresistible.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
It's just, how do we make that recurrent

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
and scale it?

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:53.958
We know also, because we're connected in social networks,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
that it's easy to create delight

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
in one little place.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
It's contagious because we're all connected to each other.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
So if I have a terrific experience

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
and I tweet it, or I tell five people standing next to me, news travels.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
The opposite, as we know, is also true,

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
often more true.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
So here we have LudoTruck, which is in L.A.,

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
doing the things that gourmet food trucks do,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and they've gathered quite a following.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:20.958
In general, and maybe, again, it's because I'm a tech entrepreneur,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
I look at things as platforms.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
Platforms are invitations.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
So creating Craigslist

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
or iTunes and the iPhone developer network,

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
there are all these networks -- Facebook as well.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
These platforms invite all sorts of developers

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
and all sorts of people

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
to come with their ideas and their opportunity

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:41.958
to create and target an application

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
for a particular audience.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
And honestly, it's full of surprises.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
Because I don't think any of us in this room

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:50.958
could have predicted the sorts of applications

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:53.958
that have happened at Facebook, around Facebook,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
for example, two years ago,

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
when Mark announced

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
that they were going to go with a platform.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
So in this way, I think that cities are platforms,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
and certainly Detroit is a platform.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
The invitation of bringing

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
makers and artists and entrepreneurs --

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
it really helps stimulate this fiery creativity

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
and helps a city to thrive.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
It's inviting participation,

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
and cities have, historically,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
invited all sorts of participation.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
Now we're saying that there's other options as well.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
So, for example, city departments

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
can open up transit data.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
Google has made available transit data API.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
And so there's about seven or eight cities already in the U.S.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
that have provided the transit data,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
and different developers are building applications.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
So I was having a coffee in Portland,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and half-of-a-latte in

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
and the little board in the cafe

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
all of a sudden starts showing me

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
that the next bus is coming in three minutes

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
and the train is coming in 16 minutes.

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
And so it's reliable, real data

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
that's right in my face, where I am,

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
so I can finish the latte.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
There's this fabulous opportunity we have across the U.S. now:

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
about 21 percent

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
of vacant commercial and industrial space.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
That space is not vital.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
The areas around it lack vitality

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and vibrancy and engagement.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
There's this thing -- how many people here

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:19.958
have heard of pop-up stores or pop-up shops?

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
Oh, great. So I'm a big fan of this.

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
And this is a very mesh-y thing.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
Essentially, there are all sorts

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
of restaurants in Oakland, near where I live.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
There's a pop-up general store every three weeks,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
and they do a fantastic job

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
of making a very social event

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
happening for foodies.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Super fun, and it happens in a very transitional neighborhood.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
Subsequent to that,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
after it's been going for about a year now,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
they actually started to lease and create and extend.

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
An area that was edgy-artsy

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
is now starting to become much cooler

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
and engage a lot more people.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
So this is an example.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:05.958
The Crafty Fox is this woman who's into crafts,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
and she does these pop-up crafts fairs around London.

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
But these sorts of things are happening

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
in many different environments.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
From my perspective, one of the things pop-up stores do

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
is create perishability and urgency.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
It creates two of the favorite words of any businessperson:

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
sold out.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
And the opportunity to really focus trust and attention

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
is a wonderful thing.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
So a lot of what we see in the mesh,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
and a lot of what we have in the platform that we built

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:36.958
allows us to define, refine and scale.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:39.958
It allows us to test things as an entrepreneur,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
to go to market,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:43.958
to be in conversation with people,

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.958
listen, refine something and go back.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
It's very cost-effective,

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
and it's very mesh-y.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
The infrastructure enables that.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:57.958
In closing, and as we're moving towards the end,

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
I just also want to encourage --

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
and I'm willing to share my failures as well,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
though not from the stage.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
(Laughter)

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
I would just like to say that one of the big things,

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
when we look at waste

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
and when we look at ways that we can really be generous

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
and contribute to each other,

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
but also move to create a better economic situation

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
and a better environmental situation,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
is by sharing failures.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
And one quick example

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
is Velib, in 2007,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
came forward in Paris

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
with a very bold proposition,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
a very big bike-sharing service.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
They made a lot of mistakes.

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
They had some number of big successes.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
But they were very transparent, or they had to be,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
in the way that they exposed

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
what worked and didn't work.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
And so B.C. in Barcelona

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
and B-cycle

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
and Boris Bikes in London --

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
no one has had to repeat

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
the version 1.0 screw-ups

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
and expensive learning exercises

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
that happened in Paris.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
So the opportunity when we're connected

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
is also to share failures and successes.

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
We're at the very beginning of something

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
that, what we're seeing

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
and the way that mesh companies are coming forward,

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
is inviting, it's engaging, but it's very early.

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
I have a website -- it's a directory --

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
and it started with about 1,200 companies,

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
and in the last two-and-a-half months

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
it's up to about 3,300 companies.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And it grows on a very regular daily basis.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:29.958
But it's very much at the beginning.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:32.958
So I just want to welcome all of you onto the ride.

00:14:32.958 --> 00:14:34.958
And thank you very much.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
(Applause)

title: On being a woman and a diplomat
transcript: Pat Mitchell: What is the story of this pin?Madeleine Albright: This is "Breaking the Glass Ceiling."PM: Oh. That was well chosen, I would say, for TEDWomen.MA: Most of the time I spend when I get up in the morning is trying to figure out what is going to happen. And none of this pin stuff would have happened if it hadn't been for Saddam Hussein. I'll tell you what happened. I went to the United Nations as an ambassador, and it was after the Gulf War, and I was an instructed ambassador. And the cease-fire had been translated into a series of sanctions resolutions, and my instructions were to say perfectly terrible things about Saddam Hussein constantly, which he deserved — he had invaded another country. And so all of a sudden, a poem appeared in the papers in Baghdad comparing me to many things, but among them an "unparalleled serpent." And so I happened to have a snake pin. So I wore it when we talked about Iraq. (Laughter) And when I went out to meet the press, they zeroed in, said, "Why are you wearing that snake pin?" I said, "Because Saddam Hussein compared me to an unparalleled serpent." And then I thought, well this is fun. So I went out and I bought a lot of pins that would, in fact, reflect what I thought we were going to do on any given day. So that's how it all started.PM: So how large is the collection?MA: Pretty big. It's now traveling. At the moment it's in Indianapolis, but it was at the Smithsonian. And it goes with a book that says, "Read My Pins."(Laughter)PM: So is this a good idea. I remember when you were the first woman as Secretary of State, and there was a lot of conversation always about what you were wearing, how you looked — the thing that happens to a lot of women, especially if they're the first in a position. So how do you feel about that — the whole —MA: Well, it's pretty irritating actually because nobody ever describes what a man is wearing. But people did pay attention to what clothes I had. What was interesting was that, before I went up to New York as U.N. ambassador, I talked to Jeane Kirkpatrick, who'd been ambassador before me, and she said, "You've got to get rid of your professor clothes. Go out and look like a diplomat." So that did give me a lot of opportunities to go shopping. But still, there were all kinds of questions about — "did you wear a hat?" "How short was your skirt?" And one of the things — if you remember Condoleezza Rice was at some event and she wore boots, and she got criticized over that. And no guy ever gets criticized. But that's the least of it.PM: It is, for all of us, men and women, finding our ways of defining our roles, and doing them in ways that make a difference in the world and shape the future. How did you handle that balance between being the tough diplomatic and strong voice of this country to the rest of the world and also how you felt about yourself as a mother, a grandmother, nurturing ... and so how did you handle that?MA: Well the interesting part was I was asked what it was like to be the first woman Secretary of State a few minutes after I'd been named. And I said, "Well I've been a woman for 60 years, but I've only been Secretary of State for a few minutes." So it evolved. (Laughter) But basically I love being a woman. And so what happened — and I think there will probably be some people in the audience that will identify with this — I went to my first meeting, first at the U.N., and that's when this all started, because that is a very male organization. And I'm sitting there — there are 15 members of the Security Council — so 14 men sat there staring at me, and I thought — well you know how we all are. You want to get the feeling of the room, and "do people like me?" and "will I really say something intelligent?" And all of a sudden I thought, "Well, wait a minute. I am sitting behind a sign that says 'The United States,' and if I don't speak today then the voice of the United States will not be heard," and it was the first time that I had that feeling that I had to step out of myself in my normal, reluctant female mode and decide that I had to speak on behalf of our country. And so that happened more at various times, but I really think that there was a great advantage in many ways to being a woman. I think we are a lot better at personal relationships, and then have the capability obviously of telling it like it is when it's necessary. But I have to tell you, I have my youngest granddaughter, when she turned seven last year, said to her mother, my daughter, "So what's the big deal about Grandma Maddie being Secretary of State? Only girls are Secretary of State."(Laughter)(Applause)PM: Because in her lifetime — MA: That would be so.PM: What a change that is. As you travel now all over the world, which you do frequently, how do you assess this global narrative around the story of women and girls? Where are we?MA: I think we're slowly changing, but obviously there are whole pockets in countries where nothing is different. And therefore it means that we have to remember that, while many of us have had huge opportunities — and Pat, you have been a real leader in your field — is that there are a lot of women that are not capable of worrying and taking care of themselves and understanding that women have to help other women. And so what I have felt — and I have looked at this from a national security issue — when I was Secretary of State, I decided that women's issues had to be central to American foreign policy, not just because I'm a feminist, but because I believe that societies are better off when women are politically and economically empowered, that values are passed down, the health situation is better, education is better, there is greater economic prosperity. So I think that it behooves us — those of us that live in various countries where we do have economic and political voice — that we need to help other women. And I really dedicated myself to that, both at the U.N. and then as Secretary of State.PM: And did you get pushback from making that a central tenant of foreign policy?MA: From some people. I think that they thought that it was a soft issue. The bottom line that I decided was actually women's issues are the hardest issues, because they are the ones that have to do with life and death in so many aspects, and because, as I said, it is really central to the way that we think about things. Now for instance, some of the wars that took place when I was in office, a lot of them, the women were the main victims of it. For instance, when I started, there were wars in the Balkans. The women in Bosnia were being raped. We then managed to set up a war crimes tribunal to deal specifically with those kinds of issues. And by the way, one of the things that I did at that stage was, I had just arrived at the U.N., and when I was there, there were 183 countries in the U.N. Now there are 192. But it was one of the first times that I didn't have to cook lunch myself. So I said to my assistant, "Invite the other women permanent representatives." And I thought when I'd get to my apartment that there'd be a lot of women there. I get there, and there are six other women, out of 183. So the countries that had women representatives were Canada, Kazakhstan, Philippines, Trinidad Tobago, Jamaica, Lichtenstein and me. So being an American, I decided to set up a caucus. (Laughter) And so we set it up, and we called ourselves the G7.(Laughter)PM: Is that "Girl 7?" MA: Girl 7.And we lobbied on behalf of women's issues. So we managed to get two women judges on this war crimes tribunal. And then what happened was that they were able to declare that rape was a weapon of war, that it was against humanity.(Applause)PM: So when you look around the world and you see that, in many cases — certainly in the Western world — women are evolving into more leadership positions, and even other places some barriers are being brought down, but there's still so much violence, still so many problems, and yet we hear there are more women at the negotiating tables. Now you were at those negotiating tables when they weren't, when there was maybe you — one voice, maybe one or two others. Do you believe, and can you tell us why, there is going to be a significant shift in things like violence and peace and conflict and resolution on a sustainable basis?MA: Well I do think, when there are more women, that the tone of the conversation changes, and also the goals of the conversation change. But it doesn't mean that the whole world would be a lot better if it were totally run by women. If you think that, you've forgotten high school. (Laughter) But the bottom line is that there is a way, when there are more women at the table, that there's an attempt to develop some understanding. So for instance, what I did when I went to Burundi, we'd got Tutsi and Hutu women together to talk about some of the problems that had taken place in Rwanda. And so I think the capability of women to put themselves — I think we're better about putting ourselves into the other guy's shoes and having more empathy. I think it helps in terms of the support if there are other women in the room.When I was Secretary of State, there were only 13 other women foreign ministers. And so it was nice when one of them would show up. For instance, she is now the president of Finland, but Tarja Halonen was the foreign minister of Finland and, at a certain stage, head of the European Union. And it was really terrific. Because one of the things I think you'll understand. We went to a meeting, and the men in my delegation, when I would say, "Well I feel we should do something about this," and they'd say, "What do you mean, you feel?" And so then Tarja was sitting across the table from me. And all of a sudden we were talking about arms control, and she said, "Well I feel we should do this." And my male colleagues kind of got it all of a sudden. But I think it really does help to have a critical mass of women in a series of foreign policy positions. The other thing that I think is really important: A lot of national security policy isn't just about foreign policy, but it's about budgets, military budgets, and how the debts of countries work out. So if you have women in a variety of foreign policy posts, they can support each other when there are budget decisions being made in their own countries.PM: So how do we get this balance we're looking for, then, in the world? More women's voices at the table? More men who believe that the balance is best?MA: Well I think one of the things — I'm chairman of the board of an organization called the National Democratic Institute that works to support women candidates. I think that we need to help in other countries to train women to be in political office, to figure out how they can in fact develop political voices. I think we also need to be supportive when businesses are being created and just make sure that women help each other. Now I have a saying that I feel very strongly about, because I am of a certain age where, when I started in my career, believe it or not, there were other women who criticized me: "Why aren't you in the carpool line?" or "Aren't your children suffering because you're not there all the time?" And I think we have a tendency to make each other feel guilty. In fact, I think "guilt" is every woman's middle name. And so I think what needs to happen is we need to help each other. And my motto is that there's a special place in hell for women who don't help each other.(Applause)PM: Well Secretary Albright, I guess you'll be going to heaven. Thank you for joining us today.MA: Thank you all. Thanks Pat.(Applause)
